üì∞Read what our Chair @Jeremy_Hunt had to say on the Government's proposals:
https://t.co/HGD40q0oLK

üìñRead our full report: https://t.co/vtxi2cVwFD

POWERS OF THE SECRETARY OF STATE‚úñÔ∏è
It is vital that local populations have confidence in NHS boards. The new proposals will give the Secretary of State the power to appoint and veto board members which raised concerns from a number of witnesses.

Our recommendation in Chapter 3: https://t.co/xAx2oYnPFt

WORKFORCE üßë‚Äç‚öïÔ∏è
We do not believe that the duty to publish an update on the roles and responsibilities once every five years (as set out by the Government) is an adequate response to workforce shortages that are endemic in the NHS.

Our recommendation in Chapter 5: https://t.co/ZHvDHptK7o

SOCIAL CARE üí∑
A long-term plan for social care was not set out in the White Paper. Without secure, long-term funding, the problems that have bedevilled the care sector over the last two decades will not be solved.

Our conclusion in Chapter 4: https://t.co/FZGKc4qa4n

How can the Government's plans to reform health and care be improved? 

In our report out today we analyse the Govt's White Paper proposals for a new Health and Care Bill and make recommendations on:

1. Social care
2. Workforce
3. Powers of the Secretary of State  

A threadüëá

NEW REPORT: Our report on the Government's White Paper for health and care has just been published.

We'll be sharing more of our findings throughout the day.

Find out more about our recommendations for the forthcoming Health and Care Bill: https://t.co/dllsUGCuTK https://t.co/hH2SXmlxtO

It's #MentalHealthAwarenessWeek 

üîäListen to Lucas giving evidence to our inquiry into children and young people's mental health. 

üìñRead the written evidence we've received on the state of services and how to improve them: https://t.co/hBxqG6mV5z https://t.co/gIMaw8MEKh

This inquiry builds on our Oct 2020 report, which called for an ¬£7bn annual increase in social care funding by 2023-24, a ¬£46,000 lifetime cap on care costs and for the Government to publish a long term plan for the social care sector.

üì∞Read more here: https://t.co/PR150uGyuP

On Tuesday we'll hold a hearing on the catastrophic care costs facing those with dementia, the difficulty accessing care and poor quality of care.

Fiona Carragher @alzheimerssoc
Caroline Abrahams @age_uk
Sarah Pickup @LGAcomms

Save the date: our report on the Government's White Paper on health and care will be published this Friday 14 May.

We've examined issues including whether the proposals will deliver integrated care, plans for the workforce, social care, and new powers for the Secretary of State. https://t.co/eqsLbOkFGF

@jesslinworld Thank you for the suggestion Liz - unfortunately it is not currently possible to display the names of speakers during live Committee meetings, but I have passed your feedback on to the Parliamentary Recording Unit.

The transcript of the full session will be available soon. 

In the meantime you can watch the session back to hear our witnesses‚Äô full testimony: https://t.co/hz7e7R6YsI (15/15)

.@Helen_Whately reiterated that a 10-year-plan for social care would be published this year, and said that the Government wanted to involve those with expertise, views and interests in making sure it gets its social care proposals right (14/15)

Asked about the Mental Health Units (Use of Force) Act, which received Royal assent in 2018, @Helen_Whately said she expects the Act to come into force in November this year. 

She said the Government has been developing statutory guidance to support its implementation (13/ 15)

.@Helen_Whately said that if the mortality review system we have isn't good enough that we should "look at it", and that the system should learn from all serious incidents 

She committed to consider proposals to improve the review system (12/15)

.@Helen_Whately said steps are being taken to reduce the use of restraint and seclusion such as improving oversight of commissioning and new staff based on the children's intervener model.

She said we should continue to reduce and stop the use of seclusion and restraint (11/15)

Asked what needed to change to reduce inpatient numbers more quickly, @Helen_Whately said there was a cross-government ‚Äòdelivery board‚Äô to overcome the barriers to this.

She said she is open to the idea of banning new admissions, but wanted more evidence of its impact (10/15)

Dr Ryan said that the current mortality review process is insufficient and highlighted the importance of a national mortality review board to investigate every death of a person with learning disabilities in an inpatient setting (9/15)

Dr Ryan questioned the high cost of inpatient units and asked why this money isn't spent on "top of the range" facilities - "gourmet menu" settings in stately homes

She asked why the NHS instead "is paying private providers ¬£11,500 a week to torture people" (8/15)

Dr Ryan said reducing the numbers of people in inpatient units depended on investment, proper enforcement of regulation and scrutinising professional practice, and shifting attitudes towards people with learning disabilities. (7/15)

Dr Sara Ryan @sarasiobhan said her son Connor's experience as an inpatient was similar to what Bengi described

She described feeling shocked at the complacency of responses to Connor's death, and how little the deaths of people with learning disabilities are investigated (6/15)

Asked what would improve things, Bengi said that the current system is ‚Äúbroken, barbaric, inhumane, antiquated‚Äù and called for a completely new model of care, and a new way of thinking and a new mindset among professionals (5/15)

Bengi described the culture of the system as being one where professionals are seen as knowing best, and families have to conform.

Bengi's daughter has been in her current unit 7 months, with no estimated date of discharge and no plan for how to get to discharged. (4/15)

Bengi described the trauma of having to watch her daughter being restrained while she was separated from her by a screen, unable to intervene or to comfort her

She also told us how her daughter was confined to a box-sized room for 4 weeks without fresh air or exercise (3/15)

Bengi O‚ÄôReilly described how her daughter, who's currently in an inpatient unit, has been treated like a criminal at times - her daughter often asks why she‚Äôs being punished

She said they have no choice, no voice, no control over 
the decisions made for her daughter (2/15)

Yesterday we held the final evidence session of our inquiry into the treatment of autistic people and people with learning disabilities. 

Here is a summary of what was discussed: (1/15)

-individuals with lived experience @sarasiobhan

üì∞Read more: https://t.co/ZGQHSz8RQk https://t.co/u89881KOoI

"A sticking plaster on a very big wound"

üîäListen to @YoungMindsUK activist Lucas telling us about his experience trying to access the mental health support he needed. https://t.co/qAmODL0L2r

The full transcript of today's session will be available soon. 

In the meantime you can watch the session back: https://t.co/kvnQXRrMmA (11/11).

On working with MHSTS, Tim Bowen, Head of Maple Primary School said that the most positive impact has been the change in culture in the school. He said that since working with MHSTs staff have been encouraged to talk positively about mental health and well-being to pupils.(10/11)

Professor @peterfonagy said that where MHSTs have been rolled out they have exceeded expectations. In a sample in London of 2300 cases Professor Fonagy said that about 60% of children seen by MHSTs were able to make a recovery. (9/11)

Asked about the rollout of Mental Health Support Teams, Professor @peterfonagy told us that the ‚Äúrate limiting factor‚Äù to faster roll out is training. He says it is important that MHST staff are not drawn away from other children and young people‚Äôs mental health provision. (8/11)

On schools, Dr Aleisha Clarke said that school based early intervention can have significant impact on students mental health. She says that universal interventions to all pupils, in combination with more targeted support, are necessary as part of a ‚Äúwhole school approach‚Äù (7/11)

Professor @PatMcGorry called the experience that young people have in transition to adult services at the age of 18 ‚Äúappalling‚Äù. Professor McGorry explained that the headspace model in Australia provides support across the range of 12-25 year-olds. (6/11)

Cassandra explained that this support that @youthaccess provides to young people is vitally important but that they must be sufficiently funded- ‚Äúit shouldn‚Äôt have to be such a battle to keep these vital services running‚Äù (5/11).

Cassandra Harrison @YouthAccess  said that community open access services provide vital support to young people who may not meet CAMHS thresholds. She told us that open access hubs can also effectively reach marginalised groups, who may fall through the gaps. (4/11)

@HopeVirgo who suffered from an eating disorder, called for services to stop using measures like BMI to determine whether to offer treatment. Hope described how damaging it can be to be told ‚Äúyou‚Äôre not thin enough‚Äù for treatment. (3/11)

We began by hearing from Lucas who described his experience of being placed on a CAMHS waiting list for 2 years. Lucas told us that his mental health struggles eventually escalated to a crisis point, which could have been avoided by earlier intervention. (2/11)

This morning we held the second session of our inquiry into children and young people's mental health. The session explored the need for early intervention and how this support can be provided in communities and schools.

Here's a summary of the key points: (1/11)

Just over a year ago we met for the first time as a Committee at the start of what became the hardest year ever for our NHS and social care system. 

The meeting was with @CMO_England and Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy CMO and was the first of many sessions we'd hold on covid-19. (1/3) https://t.co/1GHkHt6K6w

We're pleased to see Clo and Tinuke @fivexmore nominated for the Petition Campaign of the Year award for their campaign to improve maternity safety for Black women.

Last year they gave evidence to our maternity safety inquiry - you can watch it back here: https://t.co/0COXMBIbjy https://t.co/1UXoTezxgf

The full transcript of the session will be available soon.

üì∫In the meantime you can watch the session back: https://t.co/niNxgdO4qj (10/10)

On the transition from CAMHS to adult services, @claireCNWL said these should not be organised around the ‚Äúarbitrary" age of 18 and the NHS is pushing a different model which is ‚Äúneeds-based‚Äù at a time when young people are experiencing change (9/10)

On inpatient care for children and young people, including those with learning disabilities, @claireCNWL said in nearly every case it‚Äôs better for people to receive support in the community. @timkendall1 said there are structural impediments to speeding this process up (8/10)

@claireCNWL said that the NHS is making good progress against the Long Term Plan in the face of some ‚Äúreally considerable pressures‚Äù. She said the NHS has seen a doubling in eating disorder referrals during the pandemic (7/10)

Discussing regional variation in accessing support @childrenscomm said that NHS national targets allow some local CCGs to continually underperform. They are calling for more accountability for CCGs which aren‚Äôt prioritising young people‚Äôs mental health (6/10)

Mental health support teams in schools should be ‚Äúrocket-boosted‚Äù said Dame @rachel_deSouza.

Mental health services are improving but she said she would be ‚Äúexpecting to see more progress‚Äù to meet the uptick in need (5/10)

Asked about the role that schools play in mental health support, @EmmaThomasYN said that @YoungMindsUK welcomed the work of the green paper but that its training for designated senior leads should be accelerated to facilitate a ‚Äúwhole school approach‚Äù (4/10)

Lynne Green @kooth said she was really concerned about the rising numbers of children and young people experiencing eating disorders. 

She said while social media doesn‚Äôt cause eating disorders, it can make young people feel they have to strive to an ‚Äúunhealthy ideal‚Äù (3/10)

On the impact of the pandemic @SophieCorlett told us the biggest mental health effect has been on children and young people with existing conditions, those from lower socioeconomic backgrounds, young women and young people from BAME communities (2/10)

This morning we held the first of our sessions on children and young people‚Äôs mental health. The session explored issues including support in schools, regional variation in NHS support, and people experience eating disorders. Here‚Äôs a summary of the key points: (1/10) https://t.co/jmZ9quNSDA

Watch MPs debate these issues live: https://t.co/FlG9nPuJJ7 https://t.co/R5kIGftje6

üëá Important message from @DrAlexGeorge at yesterday's @CommonsEd session on young people's mental health, an issue which has never been more vital.

Our own inquiry into young people's mental health begins on 23 March with a session on the impact of the pandemic on young people. https://t.co/wVQNw5Bg6C

The full session is available to re-watch on twitter or at https://t.co/ZStPLUWnhF

The full transcript of the session will be available soon. (10/10)

On the cost of reform, @MattHancock said that the reforms would be cost saving, but was asked to write Committee outlining the balance of long-term savings against the short-term costs of re-organisation (9/10)

On social care, @MattHancock reiterated the Government‚Äôs commitment to publish options for reform before the end of the year but said that the NHS was ‚Äòcrying out‚Äô for reform and that he was committed to moving forward ahead of plans for social care reform (8/10)

On workforce, @MattHancock said the workforce reporting duty would create accountability, but workforce need is a matter of judgement

He agreed training more staff was more cost effective than employing agency staff but did not commit to providing independent estimates (7/10)

Asked about the public health elements of the White Paper, @MattHancock said these would be supported by legislative and non-legislative public health reform including elements in the Mental Health White Paper and wider public health reform (6/10)

.@MattHancock said new powers of direction for the Secretary of State will be subject to a public interest test and transparency requirements

He said clinical and "day-to-day" operational independence of the NHS will be "integral" to the drafting of clauses on new powers (5/10)

.@DHSCgovuk confirmed that the Bill will bring forward an enabling power to improve accountability for board-level appointments, such as the potential for a register of NHS managers. 

These options would be developed in the context of work ongoing by @NHSEngland (4/10)

Asked about accountability, @MattHancock confirmed the CQC will inspect the performance of Integrated Care Systems.

He said that the Secretary of State will have veto powers over board appointments made by NHS organisations, but no power of direction over purchasing. (3/10)

Discussing the recent Budget, @MattHancock said that funding for operational costs due to covid-19 in 2021/22 would be committed very shortly and said the message that these costs would be met by the Government had been made ‚Äúvery clear‚Äù to the NHS (2/10)

Yesterday we questioned @MattHancock on the Government‚Äôs White Paper for health and care. We covered a range of issues including new powers for the Secretary of State, workforce and social care.

We are delighted to announce the appointment of four Maternity Advisers to our Expert Panel:

@lregan7 @sarahnoble02 @MCR_SB_Research & Soo Downe

Find out more:
https://t.co/7yrR3VUXlR

üìó Transcript now available:

The full transcript of our session with Sir Simon Stevens and @AKPritchard2 has now been published:

https://t.co/YApN2rUjdE https://t.co/Lh0XEtCFqz

The full transcript for the session ‚Äì which was a detailed one ‚Äì will be available soon. 

In the meantime you can watch the session back here: https://t.co/DC7zqZdIRD

(10/10)

Asked about new powers for the Secretary of State, Sir Simon said there has always been close working between the NHS & Government ‚Äì the change formalises this and adds transparency

He suggested Ministers would benefit from retaining the Independent Reconfiguration Panel (9/10)

Sir Simon agreed there is a need to reform social care and provide more sustainable funding ‚Äì but said there is also a pragmatic need to get on with NHS reform. 

On workforce, Sir Simon and @AKPritchard2 welcomed the idea of independent review of long-term workforce need (8/10)

Discussing accountability, Sir Simon said that patients and their representatives will have recourse to their ICS locally and to the provider who has treated them.

@AKPritchard2 agreed there is a need to develop better mechanisms for intervening where management is poor (7/10)

Sir Simon and @AKPritchard2 spoke about how the legislation will make it easier for frontline staff to join up care in a way that makes sense for patients, but that 'humility' is needed about how much legislation alone can deliver this compared to changes to local practice (6/10)

Sir Simon and @AKPritchard2 answered questions on some of the detail of ICSs, including whether ICSs should be coterminous with local authorities, what role the CQC should play in inspecting ICSs & how the principle of patient choice will be protected in the move to ICSs. (5/10)

On the White Paper, Sir Simon defended the timing of the reforms as they are the ‚Äúconclusion‚Äù of 7 or 8 years of evolution. 

He said that in areas where there were ‚Äúbonus prizes‚Äù beyond the NHS‚Äô own consultation, there is dialogue with the Government about the details (4/10)

Sir Simon said there are uncertainties about covid costs the NHS will face in 2021/22 but that the ¬£8bn some have called for is the right ballpark.

He said there is an urgent need for additional funding for covid costs and that the NHS expects this to be resolved soon.

(3/10)

We began by asking about the Budget. Sir Simon said that NHS had previously been expecting a 2.1% increase in staff pay, and while he defended the independence of pay review bodies, he said he wants to see proper recognition of the efforts of NHS staff over the past year (2/10)

This morning we took evidence from Sir Simon Stevens and @AKPritchard2 @NHSEngland in the latest of our sessions on the @DHSCgovuk White Paper on reforming health and care.

A summary of the key points from the session is below. (1/10) https://t.co/Lh0XEtCFqz

The #socialcare funding crisis has been brought into sharp focus by the pandemic.

Today @CommonsHCLG is launching an important new inquiry into social care funding, building on the work we did jointly in 2018. 

Find out more: https://t.co/wVmmJS4mzi

Last week we held the final session of our #HSCCWorkforceBurnout inquiry, hearing from

Minister @Helen_Whately
@Prerana_Issar @NHSEngland
@AnitaCTHF
Rob Smith @NHS_HealthEdEng
Oonagh Smyth @skillsforcare 

The full transcript is now available online at: https://t.co/cbmp7d4oV3

We‚Äôll post the transcript of the session when it‚Äôs available.

In the meantime, you can watch the session back here: https://t.co/dTzATXQKjO (13/13)

Discussing the new Health Service Safety Investigations Body, @ChrisCEOHopson said there was nervousness about proposals to allow the Secretary of State to alter safe spaces.

He said there must be no political interference - and no appearance of it - in safety processes (12/13)

@SJPickup said that the social care sector would be "distraught" at the lack of action on social care in the White Paper and said that not fixing social care is a "false economy"

She also called for a new deal on pay and conditions for current social care workers (11/13)

.@NHSE_Danny agreed that accountability and transparency were important and the Bill could make the relationship between Secretary of State and @NHSEngland more transparent - but that this should include transparency if @NHSEngland disagrees with a ministerial direction (10/13)

.@ChrisCEOHopson said that he wasn't necessarily opposed to new powers for the Secretary of State to give directions or change functions of organisations but more detail was needed on their limits

He called for more detailed consultation on the specifics of these powers (9/13)

Sir Robert Francis and @ChrisCEOHopson agreed that the accountability of Integrated Care Systems would be extremely important and that accountability arrangements needed to be clarified.

Sir Robert Francis agreed that the CQC could play a role in inspecting ICSs (8/13)

Our second panel heard from leaders in the sector Sir Robert Francis QC @HealthwatchE, @ChrisCEOHopson, @NHSE_Danny and @SJPickup who discussed issues including accountability, new powers of direction for the Secretary of State, and patient choice (7/13)

.@RichardDMurray1 & @Nedwards_1 agreed placing artificial limits on training budgets means the NHS ends up with fewer professionals than it needs

@Nedwards_1 said training doctors & nurses creates highly skilled workers who benefit other parts of the economy and society (6/13)

.@RichardDMurray1 said that a five-year duty for the Government to report to Parliament on workforce was not enough. 

He said the pandemic has shown how the workforce is key: you can buy as many ventilators as you want but without staff to work them it just doesn‚Äôt help (5/13)

On social care, witnesses agreed that the White Paper represented a missed opportunity and @hugh_alderwick said the Government was prolonging an "ongoing political failure" and undermining the rest of the ambitions of the White Paper by not reforming social care (4/13)

Witnesses welcomed the triple aim for health organisations but pointed out that there were wider issues that weren‚Äôt addressed in the legislation such as workforce shortages, social care funding and wider public health reforms (3/13)

Our first panel heard from health & care experts @RichardDMurray1 @nedwards_1 @hughalderwick 

They agreed the plans are the right direction for integrated care, but legislation alone can't ensure collaboration.

The need to better define the role ICSs was also discussed (2/13)

Today we heard from health and social care leaders and experts in our first session on the Government‚Äôs new health and care White Paper.

In this thread we'll tweet a summary of key points made in the session.

You can watch the session back here: https://t.co/kDFMFi8AQr (1/13)

On Tuesday we heard testimony from @AQuinnUnbroken @TwittleyJules @VivienCooper @LearningDisEng & @dan_scorer on the treatment of people with autism and learning disabilities.

üìúThe full transcript of the session is now available online: https://t.co/KqD1I8nHy4

The transcript for the session will be available soon.

In the meantime, you can watch the session back online here: https://t.co/WhuRSHGMaO

And find out more about the inquiry on our website: https://t.co/ZGQHSz8RQk

(8/8)

Witnesses also shared concerns about the impact of the pandemic on people with learning disabilities, including the very high death rate, the removal of support, and the lack of priority attached to vaccinating people with learning disabilities and their carers (7/8)

All our witnesses emphasised that specific services, particularly crisis support, would all continue to be needed but that the right place for this is in the community, with upfront investment and wider care and support provided that is appropriate for individuals (6/8)

Witnesses were clear that the absence of community provision is a serious problem which hasn't improved, and expressed concern that without this provision, and necessary investment, no change would occur, even with changes to legislation (5/8)

Our witnesses were unanimous that in-patient settings were not the right place for the vast majority of people and spoke about examples of people who have gone from being restrained and secluded in hospital to thriving within the community within days (4/8)

.@AQuinnUnbroken said sectioning is a constant threat due to a lack of community support and a system that over-medicalises people. She said most staff tried their best but the system is unfit for purpose. She called for real change & an end to 'endless evidence giving'  (3/8)

We began by speaking to @AQuinnUnbroken who described how she was treated as less than human by the system, put at odds with herself, and for the first time made to hate the autistic part of herself (2/8)

This morning we heard from Sir Simon Stevens @NHSEngland as part of our joint #COVID19LessonsLearnt inquiry with @CommonsSTC.

This is his answer for what a new '1948 moment' for health and social care would look like.

Watch the session back: https://t.co/ocxNSzFAU7 https://t.co/nfsJIKRrA1

Our session with Sir Simon Stevens on #COVID19LessonsLearnt has now ended, with thanks to him for his time and our best wishes to the whole @NHSEngland team.

You can watch the session back here: https://t.co/MkByiHLsg5 https://t.co/SmIiM8OAbv

Asked about what he would want from another '1948' moment for the NHS, Sir Simon Stevens says a long-term plan and funding settlement for social care, and for the health service to be seen as part of the economic engine of the country, not just as something to spend money on

Sir Simon Stevens praises the role of the armed forces in the supporting the NHS but highlights the speed with which the NHS responded. He says one of the big #COVID19LessonsLearnt is that resilience in public services requires buffer and buffer can look wasteful - until it isn't

Sir Simon Stevens says investment in mental health support has been increasing but says that over and above this the NHS will need to account for new needs due to the pandemic. But he says that without increasing the mental health workforce this will be "for the birds"

Asked restoring elective care, Sir Simon highlights the need to reduce coronavirus cases; utilise partnerships with the independent sector; and change the way in which diagnostics take place at the beginning of an elective pathway by creating standalone diagnostic clinics

On reducing the administrative burden in the NHS, Sir Simon Stevens says the NHS spends less on administration compared to other healthcare systems, but says the NHS absolutely wants to continue with the spirit it has developed during the pandemic, moving fast to change practice
Our report on #socialcare which Sir Simon referred to is available here: https://t.co/qlVo0jHdYg

Asked about social care, Sir Simon reiterates the need for a long-term plan and highlights our recommendation for ¬£7bn a year extra for social care by 2023/24. He says this now looks "relatively modest" compared to emergency investment & adds "where there's a will there's a way"

Asked about NHS staff planning, Sir Simon says @NHSEngland is lucky to have a medium-term outlook of its funding but investment in staffing and capital has been more short-term. He says anything that can bring predictability in these areas would be welcome #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Sir Simon says that he and others are hopeful that in the next 6-18 months not only vaccines but also other therapies will help the NHS to manage coronavirus more effectively and therefore allow normal services to recover #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about the decision to offer a second vaccine at 12 weeks, Sir Simon highlights evidence set out by the JCVI and others - and says on a personal level he would rather his two parents had both received one dose of a vaccine, rather than one of them having received both doses

Sir Simon Stevens says there is "deep concern" about vaccine hesitancy in certain populations and says the NHS is working to overcome access issues, longstanding mistrust and systematic efforts to lie about the vaccine to minority ethnic populations #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Sir Simon confirms that the number of people waiting more than a year for non-urgent treatment has shot up to 192,000 from under 2,000 the previous year, however the total number of people on the waiting list remains lower and the median wait is falling

Sir Simon says there no part of the NHS hasn't been affected and maternity services are no different, but the stillbirth rate is coming down. He says perinatal mental health services continue to expand, but also highlights concerns about rising referrals for eating disorders

Sir Simon says there has been a recovery in urgent cancer referrals with 1.3m patients referred since March 2020, but is most concerned with cancer surgery. He says independent capacity is being utilised and people are "moving heaven and earth" to get priority 2 surgeries done

Sir Simon tells us that the NHS is in a very serious situation and at a plateau with 33,000 Covid-positive inpatients. He says that everyone who will benefit can access intensive care but that the system is stretched in an "extreme" way with 2170 surge critical care beds occupied

Our latest session on workforce burnout has now ended. Thank you to all of our witnesses.

Watch the session back: https://t.co/DHKdOQKqDZ

üìó Look out for the transcript

#HSCCWorkforceBurnout

.@Voa1234 says the NHS and social care do reflect wider societal problems but are uniquely reliant on BAME staff who make up 20% of the workforce. He says if 20% of the NHS workforce is being discriminated against, we all pay the price #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Covid-19 has been ‚Äòterrifying‚Äô for Black staff in the NHS says @Voa1234. Covid-19 is having a disproportionate impact on BAME communities. Anecdotal evidence is that Black staff continue to feel pushed into the frontline, unable to get the protection and support necessary.

.@triciaapc says staff from BAME backgrounds in social care may be prevented from speaking out as they don‚Äôt want to be labelled as challenging and difficult, feel that career opportunities may be limited, or may fear losing shifts in roles with lower pay than their NHS peers.

.@Voa1234 notes that most leaders leading the initial response to the covid-19 crisis were white. He asks: without NHS leaders from BAME backgrounds at the top of the tree, how are we going to understand the experiences of those at the bottom? #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

.@triciaapc says the issues discussed so far this morning echo those of social care, but social care is often seen as an afterthought. In a fragmented system, data is harder to capture. We need research and engagement with the workforce to capture their experience

Shilpa Ross from @TheKingsFund says that their research found issues with access to training, development and job opportunities from staff from Black, Asian and minority ethnic backgrounds #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Asked about issues facing BAME staff, @Voa1234 says leaders in the NHS aren‚Äôt held to account for leading all the people all the time. While things have improved, we have a long way to go ‚Äì the NHS is on the brink and we can't afford to have 20% of staff feeling disengaged

Helen√© Donnelly OBE says we need to make better use of Freedom to Speak Up Guardians. @NatGuardianFTSU calls for triangulation of data locally along with a change in focus nationally so that culture is put on a par with finances and performance in the NHS #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Asked whether we need Freedom to Speak Up Guardians for social care, @NatGuardianFTSU says this is a ‚Äòyawning gap' and that people have had to raise concerns directly to the CQC during the pandemic #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

.@ChrisCEOHopson says appropriate regulation is needed, as if you get things wrong in the NHS people die. The question is the degree to which local leadership is trusted to get on with doing what they need to do. In the past people have felt the approach was too prescriptive.

The NHS understands compassionate leadership is needed, says Helen√© Donnelly OBE, but when the pressure‚Äôs on that goes out the window. NHS leaders who deliver with compassion and care are seen as not robust, as lightweight, but they are the right role models #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

.@NatGuardianFTSU says speaking up is only effective if leaders listen and act ‚Äì all leaders should see this as a key part of their role. It's really important that the cultures of the national bodies improve so that leaders across the NHS can support and empower their staff

Helen√© Donnelly OBE talks about the bullying culture at Mid Staffs. If staff spoke up they were bullied and threatened, causing apathy and silence. She still sees some echoes of this in the NHS. Though it is in the minority, the results can be catastrophic #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Discretionary effort is the rocket fuel that powers the NHS' says @CEOChrisHopson. We need to find alternative ways so we can stop asking NHS staff to go the extra mile every single shift, every single day, every single week #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

For a long time, especially recently, the NHS has run on goodwill says @jfdawson76. We are relying on NHS staff to go the extra mile and a half and this is unsustainable. Stress is increasing across the board #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

.@ChrisCEOHopson acknowledges a significant problem with NHS bullying and harassment. There has been a culture of excessive focus on delivery of targets, but people now recognise that focus on targets alone is not the right way of doing things #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

For the last ten years capacity has not matched demand in the NHS, says @ChrisCEOHopson, so we've asked staff to work harder and harder and harder. A fully costed long term properly funded plan on workforce numbers is absolutely essential.

We begin by asking about the current situation in the health service. @ChrisCEOHopson says the situation on the frontline is 'incredibly serious.' There may now be more pressure for longer than expected, with the NHS 'in limbo' waiting to see whether restrictions have been enough

Our session on #coronavirus with the Secretary of State has now finished.

You can watch the session back here: https://t.co/qsnnxmdamK

üìó Keep an eye out for the transcript.
Chair @Jeremy_Hunt thanks @MattHancock - and particularly all NHS and social care staff working in what is probably the hardest week the NHS has faced

.@MattHancock says the Government is committed to the JCVI's priority list for vaccination. He say the order after that priority list (i.e. under 50s without underlying conditions) is not yet decided but that teachers, nursery staff, police & other key workers have a strong case
Asked about vaccine production and availability, @MattHancock says the key capacity constraint is supply of the vaccine but that manufacturers are working as fast as they can to produce more
.@MattHancock says that he is informed that access to twice weekly lateral flow tests for hospital staff should be 100% in England

On staff required to deliver #coronavirus vaccines, @MattHancock says training requirements such as fire safety have been removed, but acknowledges that significant pressure on hospitals due to high numbers of Covid-19 cases will limit the workforce

.@MattHancock says that advice to clinicians has changed to allow them to draw six doses not five from every vial of vaccine as long as they are full doses, with any extra doses used for NHS and social care staff

Asked about the mental health effects of #coronavirus, @MattHancock says more support is being put into mental health services and announces that a Mental Health White Paper will be launched next week with the intention to legislate a new Mental Health Act in this parliament

.@MattHancock says that while the Government will need to make political judgements in time about how to lift restrictions but that a national debate will be needed. He points out that the new variant demonstrates that we will need to continue to be vigilant

Asked about whether the NHS in London has enough capacity to cope, @MattHancock highlights steps taken to increase critical care capacity. He says reports that the Nightingale hospital has been decommissioned are "not true" but says "we also need the people"

Asked why there is not a full dashboard of vaccine data available, @MattHancock says that as the vaccination programme grows, more and more information will be put out into the public domain with the aim of increasing trust #coronavirus

Asked why community pharmacists are not delivering #coronavirus vaccines, @MattHancock says the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine wasn't appropriate for pharmacy delivery due to the cold chain needed but says delivery in pharmacy settings is increasing for the Oxford/AstraZeneca vaccine
However, he adds that the number of people in hospital with #coronavirus will likely fall more slowly as younger people tend to stay longer in hospital
.@MattHancock says he is as confident as he can be that the number of deaths from #coronavirus will fall relative to the number of cases once everyone in cohorts 1 to 4 has been vaccinated

.@MattHancock says that data shows that positivity rates are much lower among young children and that they are much less likely to suffer illness due to #coronavirus, which is why nurseries have not been recommended to close

.@MattHancock says it is for @MHRAgovuk to decide whether or not social care workers could be allowed to conduct lateral flow tests for #coronavirus at home before coming into work, but says they are looking at it

.@MattHancock is asked why the UK has not yet introduced border measures beyond quarantine to control #coronavirus - he says the UK has a targeted approach to border measures e.g. only British Nationals are allowed to travel from the UK from South Africa

Asked about why the Government did not announce new restrictions sooner, @MattHancock says that the Government increased the number of areas under Tier 4 over December and suggests that the data over Christmas was not clear enough to recommend a new national lockdown.

1/ In October we launched our joint inquiry with @CommonsSTC on the lessons learnt from covid-19. Here‚Äôs a recap of some of the key things we‚Äôve heard so far. #COVID19LessonsLearnt @Jeremy_Hunt

Our session on maternity safety is now ended. Thank you  
@fivexmore @DOckendenLtd @MidwivesRCM @RCObsGyn @Marianfknight Prof Jenny Kurinczuk and Prof Gordon Smith for talking to us.

Watch again here: https://t.co/v5SFzyUXbT

#HSCMaternitySafety https://t.co/w2AfOCFzxK

53% of maternity services were made to redeploy staff to other areas of the hospital during the first wave of the COVID pandemic, says Dr Morris from @RCObsGyn 
#HSCMaternitySafety

Professor Gordon Smith from @Cambridge_Uni
adds that maternity staff could be trained to deliver a third scan to detect breech presentation quite simply and easily. 
#HSCMaternitySafety

Quite large numbers of women currently go into labour with the baby not in a head-first position, which can lead to problems in labour, and bad outcomes. It seems self evident that a third scan to detect breech presentation would be a useful intervention, says Prof Gordon Smith.

Dr Morris from @RCObsGyn reflects there is true value in high quality local investigations especially when there is good family involvement. #HSCmaternitysafety 

Watch live: https://t.co/HSIRWxnO4s

Gill Walton from reflects that the recent @MidwivesRCM  survey highlighted that 80% of midwives don't feel safe care is being delivered because of staffing.
#HSCmaternitysafety

We are still 3,000 midwives short, says Gill Walton from @MidwivesRCM, but maternity support workers, obstetricians, anaesthetists and perinatal specialists are also crucial. 80% of staff do not feel that staffing levels are sufficient for safe care. 
#HSCmaternitysafety

There is a need to develop system changes at pace, including multi-professional working and training together says Gill Walton from @MidwivesRCM in response to the  @DOckendenLtd #ockendenmaternityreview.

#HSCmaternitysafety

Maternity services are underfunded and subject to cuts every year which is having an impact on the things we know contribute to making care safe, says the Gill Walton of @MidwivesRCM 

#HSCmaternitysafety

All women with complex pregnancies should have a consultant lead recommends @DOckendenLtd. In many cases, women in this category did not receive the referrals they needed to more specialised medical care. 

#HSCmaternitysafety
#ockendenmaternityreview

@DOckendenLtd highlighted that the Shrewsbury and Telford Trust often failed to identify the root cause of maternity failings. 

#HSCmaternitysafety

.@DOckendenLtd says when women make a choice about place of birth, we need to make sure women are making this based on the correct information.

We have asked for all trusts to make sure that they are doing this in a letter sent last night. 

#HSCmaternitysafety

It's clear that caesarean section rates at the Shrewsbury and Telford were much lower than other Trusts. @DOckendenLtd heard women were pressured into normal births. But this was not solely a midwifery issue - the problems were multi-professional in nature.
#HSCmaternitysafety

The Shrewsbury and Telford Trust did not follow the national guidelines for investigating incidents, did not identify the causes accurately and didn't learn continues @DOckendenLtd 

#HSCmaternitysafety
Donna Ockenden @DOckendenLtd tells @Jeremy_Hunt that the one thing that stands out above all else from her work at Shrewsbury and Telford is the Trust's failure to listen to families.

There are still disparities between mortality rates for babies from different ethnic backgrounds, and this disparity has NOT reduced and may have slightly increased, whilst the overall perinatal mortality rate has fallen by 15% since 2015 says Prof Jenny Kurinczuk from MBBRACE.

Tinuke @fivexmore adds that black women are not being given the information they need to make informed choices about their births.

"I had an assisted birth without having been given any information about assisted births."

#HSCmaternitysafety

Tinuke @fivexmore - my traumatic experience was not a unique one - it is backed up by the stories we have heard, and the research. 

"We think the NHS needs to commit to a target to tackle this gap for black women - this would be a perfect starting point."

#HSCmaternitysafety

The mortality rate for black mothers has grown from 3x more to 5x more in recent years, Professor Marian Knight tells the Chair @Jeremy_Hunt 

#HSCmaternitysafety

Professor Marian Knight from MMBRACE agrees with Tinuke @fivexmore that failure to listen to pregnant women from BAME backgrounds when they describe their symptoms is a key issue.

#HSCmaternitysafety

https://t.co/By0egO73z5
Professor Marian Knight tells Chair @Jeremy_Hunt that the majority of women who died have complex needs and maternity services are not set up to deal with clinical complexity.

Greater investment is needed by the NHS to understand the causes of these issues - there is a lack of involvement of black women in strategy development in this area, Clotilde from @fivexmore tells us. Morbidity - illness - and experience also need to be taken into account.

As early as 1991, when Tinuke was born, women from BAME backgrounds had poorer maternity outcomes - this has got worse over the years.

@fivexmore was founded to ensure that the problems are tackled quickly and Tinuke and Clotilde's own daughters + granddaughters do not face them

Tinuke from @fivexmore tells @SarahOwen_ she found similar experiences through @MumsandTea 

"I wasn't alone in having a poor experience and a lot of black mothers felt the same way, which increasingly became a cause for concern for me."

#HSCmaternitysafety

...In labour, her midwife did not believe Tinuke's reports of progress and pain, resulting in an assisted delivery. She describes how she was not listened to and was left feeling that she was not important. 
#HSCmaternitysafety

Tinuke from @fivexmore reports that black women have consistently poorer experiences - she describes her own pregnancy where the signs of pre-eclampsia were not picked up until very late in her pregnancy. 
#HSCmaternitysafety

.@CMO_England is asked about the decision to cease vaccination of people with history of significant allergic reactions with the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine: he says it is always better to be cautious at the beginning and completely standard practice

We resume with @CMO_England asked about the potential for rapid testing to enable 'test and release' to reduce the need for self-isolation of contacts - he says the tests may be better on balance than asking large numbers of people to self-isolate but that trials need to continue
We have temporarily suspended the session due to a fire alarm. We will keep you updated.

Asked about the public's tolerance for more restrictive non-pharmaceutical interventions to control the pandemic, @CMO_England pays tribute to the sacrifices the UK public has made and says they have saved lives

Asked about revisions to @ONS incidence modelling, @CMO_England says it's very important people don't think advice and decision-making is just based on modelling. He says his own advice is based as far as possible on hard data: "these are real people, in a bed, unwell"

On the potential for the vaccine to allow restrictions to be lifted, @CMO_England says this will be a political decision informed by science, but that very few people would recommend really removing restrictions during the winter until all JCVI priority groups are vaccinated

Sir Patrick Vallance says that early on he and others believed that trying to find a vaccine was going to be a really important part of a covid-19 response. @CMO_England adds that the establishment of the vaccine taskforce and its focus on non-flu diseases was important

Dr June Raine @MHRAgovuk says that the regulator creates a proactive plan to monitor the clinical use of an approved vaccine and yesterday began to deliver their plan for real-time vigilance of the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine

We begin this morning by questioning Dr June Raine, Chief Executive @MHRAgovuk who describes the rolling review process they have undertaken to approve covid-19 vaccines and says they are working hard to review both the Oxford and Moderna vaccines using the same process

.@rmoonesinghe describes the virtual ward programme being piloted, which has a focus on people from BAME backgrounds, monitoring people with Covid-19 in the community by measuring their blood oxygen and taking action if their blood oxygen level falls

Asked about healthcare for people with learning disabilities, @rmoonesinghe says the NHS is working through co-production with people with learning disabilities to improve access, communications and is also trying to improve data to monitory progress

.@rmoonesinghe says a lot of focus has been put on improving conditions for NHS staff from BAME backgrounds, including prior to the pandemic through the People Plan, and highlights that CQC will be inspecting employers on their progress against these commitments

.@DrHNaqvi says we know from decades of research and data that there is stratification by ethnic group in health and health inequalities, and the pandemic has shone a further light on ethnic differences in health inequalities - he says concerted work is needed to address this

Asked about the provision of PPE for NHS staff from BAME backgrounds, @rmoonesinghe says lots of work has been done to train people on fit testing for PPE, and to empower staff to raise issues. She says rapid and comprehensive action was taken once issues were raised

.@rmoonesinghe says many of the same reasons that have affected the general public - both in terms of risk of catching Covid-19 and in the risk of worse outcomes - have also impacted people from minority ethnic backgrounds working in the NHS

We are now moving onto our final panel of witnesses for our joint session with @CommonsSTC on #COVID19LessonsLearnt

We will hear from @DrHNaqvi @NHSConfed and @rmoonesinghe @NHSEngland 

üì∫Watch live: https://t.co/Fdl5zeCBVv 

Follow for more live tweetsüëáüèΩ

Asked about gaps in our understanding in the risk to people from BAME backgrounds, @IainBellONS says there are likely to be confounding factors such as the way Covid-19 is introduced into households, how able different ethnic groups are to self-isolate, and behavioural factors

.@ProfKevinFenton says there is variable implementation of recommended interventions to reduce the impact of Covid-19 on people from BAME backgrounds - he says that given the financial and economic realities of Covid-19, the provision of financial support are most important

Asked about the role of employers in protecting people from minority ethnic backgrounds, @ProfKevinFenton says many workers from BAME backgrounds felt less empowered to raise concerns about issues such as PPE or their level of risk

.@ProfKevinFenton says that social conditions have a greater impact on overall health and wellbeing than, for example, access to healthcare or genetic profile - in the case of Covid-19 he says that if you're living in poverty you will experience several related risk factors

.@ProfKevinFenton says there are biological factors across ethnic groups like immune response and susceptibility to some conditions that may make Covid-19 worse, but we're in early stages of understanding the impact on clinical outcomes - he adds there are no simple explanations

Asked about action to address health inequalities during Covid-19, @ProfKevinFenton says @PHE_uk has made 7 recommendations to mitigate the impact and is working with Integrated Care Systems and local authorities to implement

.@ProfKevinFenton says as we move into the second wave we need better data on ethnicity to allow us to evaluate how people from BAME backgrounds are affected, for example, by the take-up of new testing innovations, how messages and interventions are landing with affected groups
Thirdly, @ProfKevinFenton says existing co-morbidities common in certain groups also exacerbated illness when it was acquired and caused increased risk of death

.@ProfKevinFenton describes, secondly, how some communities were less likely to access healthcare early in the course of their disease, based on levels of trust in the healthcare system, symptom awareness, and ability to navigate the system

.@ProfKevinFenton describes three key factors identified in this work: pre-existing, long-standing inequalities such as housing conditions and health conditions meaning these communities started at a disadvantage

.@ProfKevinFenton says @PHE_uk also found that factors such as these couldn't entirely account for increase morality risk for people from BAME backgrounds and did more qualitative evaluation to identify cultural, social and contextual factors

.@IainBellONS adds that we also know that people living in high population density urban areas, and people living in deprived areas are at higher risk from Covid-19, which explains half the increased risk for men from BAME backgrounds and two-thirds of the risk for women

.@IainBellONS says ONS found four factors linked to higher mortality for certain minority ethnic groups: people from BAME backgrounds are more likely to work in roles which cannot be done from home; more likely to live multi-generational households with higher density

We are now moving onto our second panel of witnesses for our session with @CommonsSTC on #COVID19LessonsLearnt

We will hear from @IainBellONS and @ProfKevinFenton about the impact on people from BAME backgrounds

üì∫Watch live: https://t.co/Fdl5zeCBVv 

Follow for live tweetsüëáüèΩ

.@SScown points out that he was asked to give feedback on Government visitation guidance within 45 minutes - on a Saturday. He says there has to be a better way to engage with experts on the frontline

Asked how to improve guidance, @SScown says the pandemic has been challenging for everyone - but guidance could always have been clearer and briefer, and that the Government could have listened to expertise in the sector more

On guidance issued to providers, @SScown says it has often seemed illogical and contradictory, it has changed very frequently, and they have had to work very hard to help staff keep on top of changing guidance

Echoing @StowJames' earlier point, @SScown says that it does take very strong advocacy these days for people with learning disabilities to access appropriate healthcare, which has been exacerbated by Covid-19

Asked about the root causes of health inequalities for people with learning disabilities, @SScown says we have to admit the fundamental issue that people with learning disabilities are currently not valued as equal members of society, which has a range of negative impacts

.@SScown says this hasn't been the case during during Covid-19 - @DimensionsUK have had 43 people admitted to hospital during the pandemic but not been accompanied, making their treatment much more difficult

On access to healthcare, @StowJames says his brother can't describe his specific health issues which is part of why it's difficult to get him the treatment he might need - @SScown says this highlights the need for people with learning disabilities to be accompanied to hospitals

.@SScown says that the Government's eye has very much been on older people throughout the pandemic - it is for understandable reasons but it means that guidance for providers is written for large residential providers predominantly

But, @SScown adds, people with learning disabilities have faced higher barriers than usual getting NHS treatment they need, such as GPs not visiting supported living conditions, and not being able to access hospital except by calling 999

.@SScown says higher mortality from Covid-19 among people with learning disabilities may in part be due to lower life expectancy generally, and the fact that people with learning disabilities often have underlying health conditions

Responding to Ann and James' testimony, @SScown says @DimensionsUK have heard of lots of people having similar experiences, and points out that Government guidance for registered care homes has frequently been issued weeks before similar guidance for supported living
We've just heard testimony from Ann McCallum, who described the impact the pandemic has had on her as a person with learning disabilities https://t.co/UvQn9BNK6y
@StowJames says getting the right care for people with learning disabilities seems to be more of a battle than it ever has been before

@StowJames says the most worrying thing was that he felt there was a lack of understanding from his brother's care provider about their responsibilities under the Mental Capacity Act to respect his brother's individual needs
@StowJames says his family is just one of thousands or tens of thousands of families who have been denied access to their loved ones in care due to ignorance of Government guidelines and legislation

What does a sustainable #coronavirus strategy look like?

Listen to @devisridhar set out the measures she believes are still required alongside mass testing - and will be required until we have a successful vaccine.

Watch the session back: https://t.co/cHFLWMkFLq https://t.co/q2sBFzY1if

Our latest #COVID19LessonsLearnt session has now finished. Thank you to our witnesses: @devisridhar, @AlexGAThomas and the Secretary of State @MattHancock.

Watch the session back: https://t.co/cHFLWMkFLq

Look out for the transcript üìú https://t.co/yGmGggHp5t

@matthancock defends Government procurement during the pandemic and says responses to their open call for recommendations came from a variety of different sources and procurement process were always followed
On running pandemic preparedness drills in the future in settings such as care homes, @MattHancock says this is a good idea and that he will take it forward
@MattHancock says his team is working on how to harness the positive developments in the NHS during the pandemic such as in technology and diagnostic capacity
Progress is continuing on clinical protocols to improve parents' access to neonatal units, says @MattHancock, and says testing will be a key part of this, but safety needs to be maintained
@MattHancock  confirms that he has asked the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation to reconsider giving higher priority for vaccines to people with learning disabilities
@MattHancock says he will make it a priority to enable families to safely visit loved ones with learning disabilities

Asked about the impact of coronavirus on people with learning disabilities, Jenny Harries says the true risk is not known because of issues with data quality and says data quality will be a focus moving forward. She says people with Down's syndrome have been a particular focus

On visiting in care homes, @MattHancock says the Government has been working to enable this as quickly as is safe and says he is hopeful that the rollout will be available to all care homes by Christmas
@MattHancock defends decision not to publish Cabinet papers on economic assessment of measures unlike decision to publish SAGE scientific advice but agreed to discuss with the Chancellor

Asked about the economic impact of NPIs, @matthancock says tiered system was introduced to protect people in some parts of the country from more restrictive measures needed elsewhere in the UK. He says Govt feels the economic impact of these policies, but quantification is hard
@MattHancock defends the ‚ÄòEat Out to Help Out‚Äô scheme, saying supporting the hospitality industry was very important and over the summer the number of cases were very low

Asked about figures in the BMJ suggesting that rapid tests are less accurate in the field than in the lab, @MattHancock and Jenny Harries say that these issues have been considered and factored into how the tests will be deployed

Asked about the logistics of mass testing including identity assurance, @MattHancock agrees that this is very important and says that this is currently being tested in the trials in Liverpool, and will then be rolled out to NHS and social care staff #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@matthancock says he wants to see the 'massive diagnostic capacity' the UK has built up used in the future to cover people with symptoms of other illnesses. He also says he wants to see culture changes so that people don't 'soldier on' and go into work with a communicable illness

Asked about efforts to enable Christmas to go ahead when other festivals such as Diwali were not, @MattHancock says he is sensitive to this but that the Government ultimately concluded that Christmas is a national holiday and is a special time for everyone in the country

On the decision not to enact scientific advice about a 'circuit breaker' in September, @MattHancock says the Government wanted to stay with a regional tiered approach because of the significant wider impacts of a national lockdown and low prevalence rates in some areas

Asked about whether we should have locked down earlier @MattHancock says measures were put in earlier in the pandemic curve than other countries in Europe. On learning lessons from the first lockdown he highlights the efforts to keep schools open
Asked about SAGE, @MattHancock says that a wide range of expertise was listened to and objects to the suggestion that there was not enough public health expertise on the group

On Operation Cygnus, @MattHancock says lessons were learnt and it had a positive impact on our COVID response, including the fact there was draft legislation ready; but it didn't ask what type of pandemic we might face, and whether we could prevent widespread transmission

@MattHancock defends the performance of the test and trace programme because it scaled up unbelievably fast and had broken the chain of transmission 'hundreds of thousands of times' in the summer. The problem was that the overall number of cases was going up due to other factors
On the decision to stop community testing in March, @matthancock says this was a consequence of having to focus the tests on people in hospital

Asked about scientific advice, @matthancock says he was guided by the science but did not immediately follow it - and says he believes he had the best scientific advice available given we started from zero knowledge of coronavirus

@matthancock adds that after Easter he expects we will be getting back to normal if vaccines are approved - some interventions, like more handwashing, should become a normal part of life; but the more damaging aspects of social distancing should be able to be lifted by Easter

Asked what a vaccine will mean for social distancing after Easter, @matthancock says it will depend on the same metrics as are being used now - the rate of transmission of coronavirus, the number of hospitalisations with coronavirus, and the number of deaths

Thank you to our first panel @devisridhar and @AlexGAThomas.

We are now moving on to question @MattHancock - @Jeremy_Hunt opens by thanking him and his colleagues at @DHSCgovuk for all their work.

Follow for tweets üëá
Watch live: https://t.co/cHFLWMkFLq

Asked about PPE procurement and public appointments, @AlexGAThomas says it's legitimate to act quickly during a crisis and make trade offs with value for money and risk of fraud - but a crisis becomes the new normal and procurement must be regularised to ensure public confidence

@devisridhar says she has a lot of respect for @CMO_England and @uksciencechief as very senior professionals, but in the future we might need to look again at the emphasis on modelling and making sure we have the right experience on SAGE - such as public and global health

This, and the evolving situation in Italy where health services began to be overwhelmed, changed thinking and pushed us towards a lockdown, although there was always concern about the economic impact and the exit strategy says @devisridhar

@devisridhar says it is clear from early SAGE minutes this was initially perceived as an uncontrollable infection that no country would succeed in suppressing;  but then East Asian countries began to show that they were successfully controlling the virus

@devisridhar says fatigue is setting in ‚Äì in other countries people got a pay off from measures taken, that they made a sacrifice but they got back to their jobs - and in Australia and New Zealand to their big rugby games. That hasn‚Äôt happened here

Over-reaction and a speedy response is always better than watching and waiting - because this virus has a low case mortality rate and affects predominantly older people, there was a hesitancy to act says @devisridhar

One of the lessons we need to look really hard at is the national risk assessment process and the extent to which it is interrogated and challenged, says @AlexGAThomas. It's clear that references to novel coronaviruses in risk register were too dismissive #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@AlexGAThomas says the way Govt has reorganised itself to respond has been positive but there are questions about the transparency and accountability of some of the recent appointments to senior positions. He believes appointments should be competence first and politics second

@AlexGAThomas agrees that there was an bias towards optimism at the beginning of the pandemic and the severe negative consequences were hard to imagine. He says the need to wait for consensus and compelling evidence became a weakness in the early phase of the pandemic

However there were issues, says @AlexGAThomas, such as the balance between central and local responses; the effectiveness of risk planning, which was too focused on flu and didn't feed into all of Government; and communications and decision-making has been weak at times

Asked about the effectiveness of the UK state, @AlexGAThomas says coronavirus has highlighted good and bad in the British state: the initial economic response was strong and rapid; testing has been ramped up significantly; and the virus was controlled in prisons

@devisridhar says she doesn't believe the current restrictions were inevitable - she says over the summer cases were very low, if restrictions had been extended just a few more weeks and border controls maintained, this might have kept prevalence low

On Christmas, @devisridhar says the issue is that people want to hear reassuring messages, but the virus doesn't care that it's Christmas - mixing indoors, with alcohol, and with elderly relatives, is very risky #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@devisridhar says the consensus is that the UK locked down too late, and believes this was based on a false dichotomy between health and the economy - countries that chose to suppress community transmission with early, strict measures have had stronger economic recoveries

@devisridhar says it feels like the UK was too late in using border measures and travel restrictions to catch cases on entry; that testing is improving but low compliance with isolation undermines it; and communications with the public have not been clear enough

@devisridhar welcomes the development of mass testing but says it has to go with a sustainable strategy made up of test, trace and isolate, very good communication with the public, and border measures to prevent importing of infections

@devisridhar says it's clear that the UK has experienced more deaths from the pandemic and that much of this results from early decisions to treat the pandemic like flu, rather than treating it like a SARS-like event

It's not OK that we don't have a detailed plan for those 1.6 million people working in social care, @vicrayner tells us. We need a fundamental commitment to protect and support them. We have to have that People Plan and resource it properly.

@DrAdrianJames says the People Plan is amazing but a lot of staff will look at it and think 'we just don't have time for all that.' The wellbeing offer can often be lost. Wellbeing is about how are staff feeling about themselves so they can provide the best possible care.

NHS and social care organisations should take a scorecard approach to mental health says @paulfarmermind, looking at negative indicators - such as mental health sickness absence, and positive indicators - such as how many people in staff surveys feel in control of their workload.

Some social care employers are taking the lead, e.g. with mental health first aid training. But there is no clear understanding of what occupational health should be provided across organisations, says @VicRayner. All staff should have access to what is currently 'best practice.'

@vicrayner describes the heightened fear facing care staff that they might pass COVID-19 to vulnerable people they care for outside of work. Sickness days have risen from 2.9% last year to 7.5% this year which has put huge pressure on social care staff.

We went into this pandemic with high levels of stress in social care, @vicrayner tells the Committee. There was huge pressure on staff in care homes, giving end of life care without being able to share that burden with families, and no time to grieve the patients they lost.

Many NHS and social care staff have extraordinary levels of resilience, says @paulfarmermind, but everyone has their limit. Supervisors need to be aware of the signs of stress. It would be great if some services offered through the NHS were also offered to families of NHS staff.
You need to tackle the stigma within organisations and have a clear offer that every member of staff is aware of for those who are struggling, @paulfarmermind adds
Covid has provided the most enormous wake up call for the NHS about the fundamental need to look after your staff says @paulfarmermind #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

At the beginning of the pandemic, the challenging task at hand was energising: the level of innovation, the positive public response and remote working have all been positive things, says @DrAdrianJames #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Workforce burnout should be seen as primarily a patient safety issue, says @DrAdrianJames. During a pandemic, we can't do much about the primary stressors - e.g. volume of work. But we can do something about the secondary factors, such as having enough staff.

The two most important solutions to workforce burnout are reducing workload intensity and providing space for front facing staff to talk about the difficult issues they are facing, says @ClareGerada #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Doctors tend to have fewer risk factors for mental illness than the general population, @ClareGerada tells us, but are being put into impossible situations. We are seeing the trauma of COVID exposing previous trauma #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

@ClareGerada says it's not just the hours worked but their intensity that is the issue, and adds that wellbeing resources have tended to go to the hospital sector rather than primary care #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

@CNagpaul tells us that as a nation we haven't properly valued and welcomed our overseas doctors. We should recognise we are severely short of doctors and owe them a debt of gratitude #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

BAME doctors face a backdrop of serious inequalities, says @CNagpaul. They are twice as likely to report bullying and harassment, but less likely to report safety concerns for fear of being blamed. 90% of doctors who have died from COVID were from a BAME background
Investing in wellbeing is investing in patient care, says @CNagpaul. If doctors are stressed or under pressure they are more likely to make mistakes #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Research shows changes to the ways doctors see patients during the pandemic mean doctors are actually having 20% more contacts than previously, @CNagpaul says. There should be a specification on workload limits ‚Äì doctors do well beyond their contracted hours.

Seeing so much illness and death during the pandemic is something no doctor or nurse was prepared for, says @CNagpaul. Doctors told @TheBMA about the emotional impact of holding a smartphone so dying people could communicate with relatives, or treating their own colleagues.
Even before the pandemic 80% of doctors reported being at very high risk of burnout, with 40% reporting anxiety, depression or burnout, says @CNagpaul #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Discussing staffing in cancer services, Denise Crouch @Mac_Campaigning says the one in two people who will get cancer are going to need more support. She says we need the staff to be able to deal with patients, and late referrals are going to need more input.
During the first wave of COVID-19 it felt like 'Groundhog Day every day', says Denise Crouch @Mac_Campaigning. She was shattered but says she also felt privileged to contribute.

We're hearing from Denise Crouch @Mac_Campaigning  first of all, who talks about the added pressure COVID-19 put on nurses, who are ‚ÄòCOVID-fatigued.‚Äô She herself worked long hours, being redeployed on top of her day job #HSCCWorkforceBurnout
