Our joint #COVID19LessonsLearnt session with @CommonsSTC on Test and Trace is now finished. 

Thank you to all of our witnesses.

üì∫Watch the session back: https://t.co/fCYi98Xxhi

üìóAnd look out for the transcript. https://t.co/BXrntlbwfd

@didoharding says her and her team is still focussed on covid, but agrees that we have built a very large diagnostic industry and says it's important to make sure the country benefits from that going beyond covid, including treating other diseases #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@didoharding acknowledges SAGE advice that testing and contact tracing has to happen within 72 hours to be effective but says that she can't give an average for the proportion within 72 hours that Test and Trace is achieving - developing this figure is a priority, she says

Asked again about supporting people to self-isolate, @didoharding says Test and Trace was advocating for increased financial support before the ¬£500 payment was announced recently, and worked with local authorities to improve signposting to local resources

@didoharding says that Test and Trace has delivered on all of its commitments including available testing capacity and the number of testing sites. But she says that there are areas for improvement including turnaround times and contact tracing

@didoharding says that testing volume was prioritised during September because of increasing demand, but turnaround are now being prioritised and are improving week on week. She says that last week just under 60% of care home tests came back within 48 hours

Asked about national versus local contact tracing, @didoharding confirms local tracing has achieved close to 100% contact rates compared to 50% nationally, and the rates have been relatively stable. But she says the national system is dealing with much higher volumes

Asked about private sector involvement in Test and Trace, @didoharding says she believes they are procuring things professionally and efficiently. She says the service benefits from the same rates that the Government has negotiated with companies as part of the Covid response

@SMHopkins says winter will increase demand due to increased amounts of colds, flus and winter illnesses with similar symptoms to covid. NHS Test and Trace has capacity for 500k tests per day but will need more, so is focusing on rolling out rapid tests to health and social care

@didoharding rejects the idea that NHS Test and Trace didn't predict an increase in demand in September when schools returned, but says they may not have got the scale of increase right. She says she defers to clinical experts in predicting when the next demand increase will be

@didoharding says she doesn't think testing capacity could have been scaled up any quicker over the summer than it was and suggests anyone who wants a test, anywhere across the country can get a test today - with an average travel of below 3 miles in England

Asked about the need for the state to support isolation, @didoharding agrees that financial support is important because when people don't isolate it is for reasons like needing to provide for their families. But she says the amount of support is a matter for the Govt

@didoharding outlines the various challenges at all stages of ensuring an effective test trace and isolate system, though she suggests that the system is continuing to improve. On isolation she says 54% of people do isolate but when they don't it's usually for legitimate reasons

Asked why we failed to prevent a second wave despite increased test and trace capacity, @didoharding points out we are in a different position to March where the 'R' number was much higher. @SMHopkins says that even in the summer when cases were low there was still transmission

@didoharding says she thinks that local and national contact tracing is not an either/or choice but that both parts of the system are important and should both be funded effectively #COVID19LessonsLearnt

The final panel of this morning's #COVID19LessonsLearnt session is now beginning.

We are questioning @didoharding and @SMHopkins from NHS Test and Trace.

Keep watching and following live tweets: https://t.co/fCYi98Xxhi

üëá

Prof Dr Gerard Krause says local health departments are responsible for compensating people asked to self-isolated, but this hasn't been claimed often because of wider aspects of employment support such as 'short work' where the Government tops up part time salaries to full time

Prof Dr Gerard Krause also adds that contact tracing in Germany has been core part of the strategy from the outset and throughout - and has been the responsibility of local public health departments. Despite decades of underfinancing and understaffing, they have done a good job

He says running a PCR test is not magic - and in Germany there was never a notion that one centralised lab would claim to be the only one to know how to run COVID tests. He adds that there were financial incentives for smaller labs to run COVID tests #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Professor Dr Gerard Krause @Helmholtz_HZI says it may be too early to judge why - and whether - Germany has performed better during the pandemic. But he says that German healthcare is very de-centralised which enabled testing capacity to be upscaled very quickly

Professor Sir John Bell says that rapid testing can support contact tracing and isolation - isolating contacts is not very effective but is difficult for people asked to isolate. Rapid tests could be used to test contacts of positive cases to release them from isolation

@JoMartin_path is asked about how to use new lab capacity in the future - she says this won't be our last pandemic, so we will always need stand-up capacity for major incidents and major disease outbreaks. She adds that progress in IT infrastructure has been a major success

Professor Sir John Bell and @JoMartin_path both agree that the use of rapid population testing is not a risk removal strategy and must sit alongside other appropriate infection control such as PPE use in the NHS and social distancing

@JoMartin_path says NHS pathology labs process 1.1bn tests per year so they were well set up for high volume testing. She says the decision to set up independent labs, where data didn't flow well into the NHS and public health, is something we've learnt from #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about the scaling up of lab capacity through smaller labs, @JoMartin_path says smaller NHS labs were desperate to ramp up testing in the early part of the pandemic but faced significant constraints, especially in the supply of testing materials #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Professor Sir John Bell and @JoMartin_path agree that there is significant potential for population level testing using new technologies - but there are challenges including making sure we have enough equipment, making sure tests are distributed effectively, and effective IT
John Bell reiterates that he thinks we have a 70-80% chance of things being back to normal by Easter - provided there aren't significant problems with vaccine distribution

Professor Sir John Bell is asked about his optimistic comments yesterday about the Pfizer candidate vaccine - he says there are challenges but people shouldn't underestimate the importance of the announcement: there are many pathogens we haven't found a vaccine for after decades

We are now moving onto question our second panel, including @JoMartin_path, Professor Sir John Bell and Professor Dr Gerard Krause, @Helmholtz_HZI

Keep following for live tweets üëá

@BWDDPH suggests people may be underreporting contacts to national Test and Trace to protect them from self-isolating. He calls for a stronger system of support & welcomes the ¬£500 payment for people self-isolating, which is being highly utilised in his area #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@BWDDPH says national Test and Trace seems to work relatively well in more affluent communities, but amongst poorer communities and BAME communities such as in Blackburn and Darwen, its success rates are very low.

He says if locally they had the same proportionate level of resource as the national contact tracing team, Lancashire would have 600-700 staff, which would make a transformational difference. He argues for a blended system with some national resource but more locally

@BWDDPH outlines Blackburn with Darwen's local approach which has an 89% success rate. He says people respond better to a local number and local voice; those running the system known the local community well, particularly BAME communities, and can provide wraparound support

@BWDDPH says we need unambiguous guidance - over the summer control measures were changed with rapid frequency, causing confusion among affected populations. He says we need a simple set of guidelines, particularly for areas that will continue to have high rates transmission

@profchrisham agrees that testing, tracing and isolating need to work together seamlessly. Prof Dame Anne Johnson emphasises the need to have clear and consistent messaging about individual responsibilities, as well as working directly with different communities

Asked whether we're expecting too much of contacting tracing, Prof Dame Anne Johnson agrees with @profchrisham that summer was the time to use local teams to get on top of outbreaks. She says it has to be matched with isolation, enabled by physical, social and financial support

Discussing the decision to stop community testing and contact tracing in March, @profchrisham describes this as a sad decision but says it was necessary due to a lack of testing capacity. Prof Dame Anne Johnson points out the importance of isolation during this time

He adds that there has been a shift from the national to local but it's been too slow, and if the Government had moved more quickly over the summer to shift contact tracing locally, we'd be in a better place now #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@profchrisham says the difficulty we've had with contact tracing is that the Government has built a test, trace and isolate system too biased towards the national level, and was too late in providing resources and staff at the local level where most of the effective work happens

Our second #HSCMaternitySafety session has now finished.

Thank you to all of our witnesses, in particular @JamesTitcombe and @Darrenasmith for sharing their moving testimony about the deaths of their sons, Joshua and Isaac. 

üì∫Watch the session back: https://t.co/6XIyQQ9zn2 https://t.co/fLQAgYziYj

@DrJennyVaughan endorses Dr MacLeod's testimony and agrees that no-blame compensation would offer wider restoration for more families, and using the criteria of avoidable rather than negligent would change the system overnight and create a more open, learning culture

Dr Sonia MacLeod says in New Zealand when they made a similar shift, the average time for claims to be process dropped from more than 5 months to 13 days, meaning faster resolutions for families and faster learning. Clinicians were prepared to say "something went wrong"

Dr Sonia MacLeod says implementation of the rapid resolution and redress scheme, as set out in Better Births, is essential - working not on a negligence threshold for redress but an avoidable threshold, similar to in Sweden #HSCMaternitySafety

Dr Sonia MacLeod @OxfordCSLS reflects on the struggle that @JamesTitcombe and @Darrenasmith described, saying that what is needed is both reducing avoidable harm, and delivering redress when people are affected by harm - but litigation is currently the only way to obtain redress

Reflecting on the role of the @gmcuk, @DrJennyVaughan says the GMC is important in ensuring patients can trust that their doctor can meet certain standards. She says the GMC has learnt a lot since the Bawa-Garba case but issues remain, particularly related to BAME doctors

@DrJennyVaughan says when something goes wrong, families need support, openness, an apology, and compensation; the most important thing for clinicians is to be able to speak openly about what has gone wrong and learn from it without fear. Fixing both will have a very big impact

@DrJennyVaughan says this is not necessarily just about the law - organisations like @NHSEngland and @NHSResolution need to specifically embrace a just culture which is not about no blame but openness, accountability and learning #HSCMaternitySafety

@DrJennyVaughan: One of the most important things is stopping defensive medicine and stopping clinicians from hiding their errors - without this it is impossible to promote learning and you will get a worsening culture of defensiveness #HSCMaternitySafety

@DrJennyVaughan reflects that the system needs to change. Tort law, finding fault, is not the solution in most cases - the system needs to bring in candour and apology so people feel confident to speak out and admit their error knowing they won‚Äôt be blamed for it

@DrJennyVaughan says the biggest barrier to safety in the NHS is its toxic blame culture - we need to promote an open culture, honesty about mistakes, and getting initial investigations right #HSCMaternitySafety

We are now moving onto our final panel in this session, which will discuss the NHS's culture around mistakes:

@DrJennyVaughan 
Dr Sonia MacLeod @OxfordCSLS

#HSCMaternitySafety

Dr Pelle Gustafson says one of the main parts of the Swedish project has been to reduce the hierarchy between doctors and midwives, and that the fact that this hierarchy persists in the UK is one of the big differences #HSCMaternitySafety

He describes the difference between the UK and Sweden - if care was not given in accordance with best practice compensation can be given. There is no need to prove negligence. He says the bar is lower in Sweden but that it is not dangerous to admit something didn't go as expected

Reflecting on the Swedish experience, Dr Pelle Gustafson says the best injury is an injury that doesn't happen, but that if disaster does strike you need a system that provides candour, apology and some type of compensation #HSCMaternitySafety
Helen Vernon says Trusts are being specifically advised to preserve records of clinical care during lockdown following an increase in stillbirths during first lockdown #HSCMaternitySafety
@NHSResolution only sees the tip of the iceberg, says Helen Vernon. We don't see the near misses. There is lots of information that is relevant that could be learnt from #HSCMaternitySafety

Helen Vernon @NHSResolution says the challenge in resolving litigation is in causation. You can establish that something may have gone wrong. But establishing that, for example, mistakes specifically caused a brain injury can take many years

Responding to @JamesTitcombe and @Darrenasmith's moving testimony, Helen Vernon @NHSResolution expresses her admiration and says teamworking, especially during emergencies, and openness and leadership, come up again and again in claims #HSCMaternitySafety

We are now moving on to question our second panel of witnesses:

Helen Vernon, Chief Executive @NHSResolution and Dr Pelle Gustafson, CMO at @Lof_sverige 

üëá

@Darrenasmith reflects on his experience of litigation, saying that it prevents you from grieving, and extends your suffering - he says the whole medical negligence process "is made to be a battle", not to promote learning or improve care #HSCMaternitySafety
@Darrenasmith says he and his wife pursued legal action simply because they wanted an apology. They felt it was the only way they could get one

@Darrenasmith says he and his wife were fortunate in having the skills to question the Trust's inadequate response to Isaac's death - but many people might not be able to do the same, such as people who don't speak English as a first language #HSCMaternitySafety
Reflecting on the failings in his wife and son's care, which led to Isaac tragically passing away aged 6 days, @Darrenasmith describes the Trust's response to these events as 'appalling'

@Darrenasmith tells us about the heartbreak of losing his son Isaac. He describes the "shutters coming down" when they tried to get answers from the hospital and the inadequacy of inquiries into Isaac's death.

@JamesTitcombe says problems in maternity units need strong team work between doctors and midwives to address them - this wasn't the case in Joshua's care. He adds that every serious incident needs to be investigated, but that this still isn't happening #HSCMaternitySafety

@JamesTitcombe reflects on changes since Joshua's care at Morecambe Bay - he says that some improvements have been made but others are repeating themselves. Families are still having to act as the 'canary in the mine' for problems, rather than them being picked up by the system

@JamesTitcombe tells us about his baby son Joshua's desperate struggle for life. He says the unit where Joshua was cared for was dysfunctional, and says there was a 'cultural turf war' between midwives and doctors during his care

@Prerana_Issar reiterates that the NHS does need more staff and she is asking for more investment in creating more training places across the board, and she says it would be "really, really difficult" if that investment is not available #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

On support for those in social care, @Prerana_Issar says the People Plan will be delivered through local health systems. Some health and wellbeing offers are available to social care staff but there are constraints related to funding and statutory responsibility

Claire Murdoch says she is confident that @NHSEngland will be able to move very fast with regards to getting the newly-announced measures in place. Although rollout will be rapid, it will begin where it is needed most #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Over a million health and wellbeing conversations have taken place in the last few months in the NHS, says @Prerana_Issar. This is being tracked within every system, and is a huge and necessary step forward #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

On wellbeing in the NHS, @Prerana_Issar says at all levels every manager and leader is engaging with staff to see how they're doing. A fortnightly survey has run since July - 61.6% of staff feel able to have a work life balance, and 67.6% feel supported by wellbeing offers

Claire Murdoch @NHSEngland announces to the Committee that they will be investing ¬£15 million in a winter support fund to make sure all NHS staff can get rapid assessment and treatment for mental health issues #HSCCWorkforceBurnout
Health and Social Care Committee Chair @Jeremy_Hunt calls for the recommendations on staffing numbers needed to deliver the Long Term Plan to be published #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

@Prerana_Issar tells us @NHSEngland have done modelling with Health Education England on the staffing numbers needed to deliver the Long Term Plan and have made recommendations to the Treasury based on those ahead of the Spending Review #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

@WestM61 says we don't have sufficient data yet on how the fear of contracting COVID-19 or passing it on to patients impacts staff stress but early indications, including over half a million contacts to @NHSEngland's support services set up for staff, show impacts are high.

On the issues faced by BAME staff, @WestM61 says action is needed on three levels: structures and processes, training leaders to lead in an inclusive way, and making sure that everyone in an organisation feels responsible for promoting inclusive and compassionate culture

@ProfMartinGreen says a People Plan for social care would start with a vision for what social care delivers, and look at the levels of skills and competencies required, providing career escalators. The NHS's training budget could be opened up to social care HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Caroline Waterfield @NHSemployers agreed the NHS People Plan lacked a longer term focus. There needs to be a focus on addressing vacancies, but also going beyond the number of doctors and nurses and integrating smaller professions e.g. pharmacists more fully.

@ProfMartinGreen says the problems are similar in social care but it's a fragmented system without data like the NHS staff survey or a People Plan. He says social care needs an integrated workforce plan to meet the challenges of the future #HSCCWorkforceBurnout
@WestM61 adds that without a plan to fill vacancies and reduce attrition we'll be in trouble #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

@WestM61 says chronic excessive workload in health and social care is like the pattern on the wallpaper that we no longer see - it's the number one predictor of staff stress, intention to quit, patient dissatisfaction and it's highly associated with errors #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

@WestM61 says the NHS People Plan begins to identify some key factors influencing wellbeing and focuses on building effective compassionate teams. But we don't yet have a detailed workforce strategy for the future - it's like a smart-looking car without an engine

Professor @WestM61 defines burnout as what happens when demands on us at work exceed the resources that we have to respond to them. It's a combination of emotional exhaustion, depersonalisation or detachment from work, and a feeling of lack of accomplishment #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

We are now moving onto our second panel of witnesses - @WestM61 @ProfMartinGreen and Caroline Waterfield @nhsemployers

#HSCCWorkforceBurnout

üì∫Watch live here: https://t.co/cbrC1SXLzA 

Follow for more live tweetsüëá

Jo Da Silva says care staff should be recognised for going above and beyond their roles due to COVID-19, and should be seen as on a par with other professionals. Care workers do so much more than personal care, and the positives need to be highlighted. #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

During COVID-19, care staff have found themselves staying with clients for longer periods of time than allocated and taken on extra duties, says Jo Da Silva. This happened before the pandemic but has increased. #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

Jo Da Silva tells the #HSCCWorkforceBurnout inquiry that COVID-19 boosted morale by bringing people together, and the public's eyes have been opened to what care workers do. Care workers have sometimes taken on the role of family members doing extra shopping and medication duties

Bernie Miller tells the Committee about a range of measures that have supported staff at her Trust during the COVID-19 pandemic, amidst the challenges presented by the virus - including difficulties in communicating with patients whilst in PPE #HSCCWorkforceBurnout

The importance of regular coronavirus testing in social care was a key topic in our first #COVID19LessonsLearnt session with @CommonsSTC today.

Here's what @KathyRobertsMH said about the current effectiveness of testing in social care.

Watch the session: https://t.co/pfE4AN2aNv https://t.co/PKSh42Tscf

The first evidence session for our joint inquiry with @CommonsSTC into #COVID19LessonsLearnt has now ended.

Thank you to all our witnesses and viewers. 

üíª Watch again: https://t.co/f5LugmbWBv

üìÉ Look out for the transcript https://t.co/0d2H0bAey3

Asked about the experiences of Helen Spalding, @Helen_Whately pays tribute to unpaid carers and says the Government has been working with charities, local authorities and others to try to ensure they have more support

On testing, @JaneMCummings says over 15,400 care homes are currently taking part in regular testing, but says there are some issues with increasing turnaround times - but that median times for results to be returned is coming down again #COVID19LessonsLearnt

However, she says improvements are taking place all the time, for example in enhanced healthcare - care homes are now assigned a primary care network for support. "We're not waiting for an announcement of reform to be making progress on how the system works" says @Helen_Whately
@Helen_Whately says she is committed to long-term reform of social care but cannot give any further information on the timeline for proposals to be published #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@25DavidPearson says everyone must have a clear outcome for a test on leaving hospital, there must be good information to help with their care, cohorting and zoning is the gold standard, and plans need to be agile in light of new information about the virus.

On rapid discharge to social care, @Helen_Whately says in every area facilities are now being accredited by the CQC as having the gold standard for infection control, so patients can be discharged to specific locations safely. #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about scientific advice given on social care, @Helen_Whately describes a range of advice including from international counterparts, Public Health England and the Deputy CMO. She says she did not see a forecast of fatality rates for the care sector

@Helen_Whately says visiting is really important and the Government really wants it, but it has to be safe - she says the Government will soon pilot the proposal for named family members to be treated as key workers and allowed to visit with testing and PPE

Asked about agency workers working across different care homes, @Helen_Whately says the Government has now moved to mandating agency workers to work in only one setting, support by infection control funding #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked whether care homes should have been prevented from admitting residents from hospital if they weren't capable of isolating them effectively, @Helen_Whately says that the winter plan for social care now has a specific requirement to ensure care homes are able to do this

Now onto the final panel of today's session with @CommonsSTC on #COVID19LessonsLearnt

We will be questioning Care Minister @Helen_Whately  @JaneMCummings @25DavidPearson and Michelle Dyson @DHSCgovuk

üì∫Watch live here: https://t.co/f5LugmbWBv

More live tweetsüëá

@mancunianmedic agrees there were underlying structural problems with the funding of social care before the pandemic - he says now at least we have them in the spotlight. He'd like to see a cross-party solution that does not exclude informal carers #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Asked about additional funding for social care, @KathyRobertsMH says care homes are being able to access additional funding but that ultimately there is not enough funding going into social care. @drjanetownson agrees that homecare was grossly underfunded before the crisis

He says a strong social care voice at national planning discussions may have stopped some of these problems happening - protect the NHS essentially meant 'protect acute hospitals' #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@mancunianmedic says during the beginning of the pandemic there wasn't enough testing in all settings, there wasn't enough PPE, particularly in social care, and the health sector did not fully appreciate the difficulty of isolation control within care homes. #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@drjanetownson says social care is treated like a Victorian child, thrown scraps under the table from the NHS - she says we still have a long way to go before social care workers are seen as an integral part of the system #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@KathyRobertsMH says infection control guidance for social care needs to be more specific for providers and highlights work with @CareQualityComm in this area. She agrees that lessons learnt from COVID need to be integrated into the CQC inspection process going forward.

On testing, @KathyRobertsMH also says turnaround times are not as good as they need to be: in care homes, results are generally coming back in 2-4 days, with a lot of regional variation #COVID19LessonsLearnt

@KathyRobertsMH says the testimony of Philip, Helen and Theresa shows the stark reality of the impact of the pandemic on individuals, families and providers - and the lack of parity between the NHS and social care #COVID19LessonsLearnt

We are now moving onto our second panel of witnesses - @drjanetownson, @KathyRoberts and @mancunianmedic for our joint inquiry with @CommonsSTC on #COVID19LessonsLearnt 

üì∫Watch live here: https://t.co/f5LugmbWBv

Follow live tweetsüëá

Theresa says that testing has now improved and her home is now getting weekly testing, but the turnaround times are not good enough - one member of staff had to wait 9 days for a test result #COVID19LessonsLearnt
It was extremely hard for families, says Theresa, not knowing whether their relatives were covid-positive, or whether or not they could give them a hug or a kiss in their final days.

She says she definitely felt pressured to admit residents without knowing their COVID status. At the beginning, Testing was non-existent, she says - care homes were not a priority for the tests that were available #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Theresa Steed, a care home manager, says the biggest impact on care homes during the first wave of the pandemic was hospitals being asked to empty their beds - she says there was not enough information on whether patients were COVID-positive or not #COVID19LessonsLearnt
She adds that clearer guidance would have helped her as a carer - she was getting contradictory information about her daughter's risk from coronavirus #COVID19LessonsLearnt
Asked what support could have helped her, Helen says that mental health support could have been quicker - it took 3 months to get Maja the help she needed #COVID19LessonsLearnt
Describing the impact on herself, Helen describes having to be alert and on it from the moment her daughter woke up - she says it was just such hard work - it was non-stop

Helen Spalding, whose daughter Maja has a genetic disorder, describes the 'tailspin' that her daughter went into when all of her support was removed at the beginning of lockdown - without her specialist college and social clubs, her mental health declined severely

He tells us he feels like care homes were sidelined during the beginning of the pandemic and should have been more of a focus. He says there was a lack of liaison between the NHS and social care, which is an ongoing problem #COVID19LessonsLearnt

Philip Scott is unable to visit his mother Sylvia in her care home in Lancaster: he tells us that the last time him or his sister were able to hug his mum or hold her hand was in February. He describes how anxious he felt because of the impact the virus has had in care homes

Are a small number of maternity services affected by safety issues, or are they more widespread? #HSCmaternitysafety

üëÇListen to Professor Ted Baker of @CareQualityComm talk about how common maternity safety issues are.

üëâWatch the whole session: https://t.co/buYHrdorLW https://t.co/4HbZzXh0LM

Today Michelle @CfSaferBirths bravely shared with us the story of her son Louie's death in hospital.

She had to go through over four years of litigation to find out the truth. How can we learn from her experience?

üì∫Full session: https://t.co/PbXpp4dncV 

#HSCmaternitysafety https://t.co/K1DNmvomlZ

Chair @Jeremy_Hunt thanks Michelle @CfSaferBirths for her important testimony, as well as Dr Bill Kirkup, Professor Ted Baker, @matthewcjolly & @TeamCMidO for their evidence.

You can watch the session here: https://t.co/PbXpp3VMln

Join the discussion using #HSCmaternitysafety

@TeamCMidO says research is being funded to better understand the reasons why Black and Asian women and babies are more at risk of dying and we hope that the results of this will be published before Christmas. We are asking services to deliver care proportionate to women's risk

@TeamCMidO highlights data which shows pregnant women who are Asian are 4 times more likely to be admitted to hospital with covid, with Black women 8 times more likely. There is a 4-point plan which they are working with services to deliver to increase support for at-risk women

Asked about maternity services during the pandemic, @matthewcjolly says he knows how important it is for women to have partners or loved ones with them during key events, but it's been a difficult balancing act to maintain services and maintain safety #HSCmaternitysafety

@TeamCMidO says we need to recognise safety concerns earlier before it escalates into a CQC 'requires improvement' rating. The maternity safety support programme helped 9 trusts in its first year, with 12 trusts currently on the programme #HSCmaternitysafety

@TeamCMidO acknowledges concerns around the term 'normal birth' but says in engaging with diverse groups of women she has heard different views including those who don't understand 'unassisted birth' - she says the challenge is what surrounds the concept of 'normal birth'

To achieve equity for the women we care for we need to go the extra mile for the most vulnerable, says @matthewcjolly - for example through the Saving Babies' Lives care bundle which seeks to identify people at greatest risk to target best quality care #HSCmaternitysafety

Asked about people feeling shut out from the system after they are affected by a tragedy - which Michelle @CfSaferBirths described - @matthewcjolly says new investigations - both independent and internal - are improving objectivity and can be trusted #HSCmaternitysafety

@matthewcjolly thanks Michelle @CfSaferBirths for her bravery sharing her and Louie's story, and particularly for her campaigning - getting the messages out is making a difference, he says. Interventions are being made to stop the same things happening again #HSCmaternitysafety

We are working really hard to achieve ambitions says @TeamCMidO - for example in stillbirths there has been a 21% fall in the stillborn rate between 2010 and 2018. The 2020 ambition has been met ahead of schedule. But we still have a long way to go #HSCmaternitysafety

We are now moving on to question @TeamCMidO and @matthewcjolly about the work they are leading at @NHSEngland to halve neonatal deaths, still births, maternal deaths and brain injury by 2025 #HSCmaternitysafety

Professor Ted Baker says women are equal partners in safety, not receivers of safety. They help drive their own safety & the safety of services. The sense of normality versus intervention is nonsense: women must have what is right for them in the circumstances #HSCmaternitysafety

Ted Baker agrees, saying women should be given choices based on their individual needs, not being told you have to do it this way or that way. 1 in 6 women in labour raise concerns about their safety during labour with their clinicians but feel that these are not taken seriously

Asked about possible over-emphasis on 'normal' births, Bill Kirkup says there is a too simplistic framing that we can either have lots of interventions and it'll be safe, or a 'normal' birth that is less safe. He says we can lots of appropriate 'normal' births and a safe service
There is a role for everyone in addressing blame culture, says Ted Baker.  We are all part of the solution as well as part of the problem #HSCmaternitysafety

Asked about training, Bill Kirkup says it was disappointing that funding for multidisciplinary maternity safety training was withdrawn after a year - evidence showed the training was effective. It would have had a net negative cost in terms of litigation and human loss avoided

Asked about differences in outcomes for Black and Asian mothers, Professor Baker says we need to do more to understand the data - but he is frustrated by hospitals sometimes trying to blame poor outcomes on demographics, rather than trying to address issues #HSCmaternitysafety

Ted Baker says staff recruitment and retention is key to maternity safety - there are locations where it's very difficult to recruit staff - that can be a serious factor in standards slipping. @CommonsHealth will be exploring this more widely in our #HSCCWorkforceBurnout inquiry

Ted Baker agrees, saying that clinicians have to accept their own and others' fallibility - the professional response to mistakes must be to investigate thoroughly, openly and honestly and learn from that to prevent similar mistakes being made #HSCmaternitysafety

Asked about safety culture among clinicians, Bill Kirkup says he wishes someone had sat him down when he was about to qualify and said, "You will make mistakes, people will be harmed and you'll feel terrible - but you have to be open and to learn from them" #HSCmaternitysafety

Ted Baker says maternity safety is a challenge for the whole system - we all need to work together to drive the cultural change needed. He says if people think we aren't making any progress it's a challenge to keep raising the problem until it's been solved #HSCmaternitysafety

Morecambe Bay report is key, says Ted Baker. It talks about defensive culture, dysfunctional teams, poor investigations, poor risk management, safety lessons not learnt: these are still being found by @CareQualityComm - five years on we still haven't learnt all the lessons

Improvements are not happening as rapidly in maternity as in other services, says Ted Baker. 38% of maternity units are rated as 'requires improvement' for safety by @CareQualityComm - this is higher than other specialties #HSCmaternitysafety

@CareQualityComm found a spectrum of quality across maternity units, says Ted Baker. In a minority, there are problems of poor leadership, dysfunction and culture, with doctors and midwives not working together well. But it is more prevalent than first thought #HSCmaternitysafety

A lot of work has gone into improving safety in maternity services, but there is still a lot we don't understand, says Bill Kirkup. The work being led by @TeamCMidO and @matthewcjolly at NHS England is very good but isn't getting to the places that need it #HSCmaternitysafety

Michelle Hemmington @CfSaferBirths asks those working to improving maternity safety to remember that parents have been there since the start and to take parents experience into account #HSCmaternitysafety

Michelle @CfSaferBirths calls for independent investigations of baby deaths and for full-term still births in labour to be reported to the coroner to publish prevention of future death reports. She also calls for more staff on wards and better team working #HSCmaternitysafety

Michelle @CfSaferBirths tells the Committee that the hospital where her son died still has not apologised to her. She asks - if a hospital cannot accept that things have gone wrong, how can they learn? #HSCmaternitysafety

Michelle @CfSaferBirths gives her brave and powerful reflections on losing her son, Louie, and on trying to get answers. She tells us how the hospital's investigation found multiple failings, but it took four and a half years before the hospital admitted fault in Louie's death.

Tune in TODAY at 9:30am for the first evidence session of our inquiry into the safety of maternity services in England. 

üó£Ô∏è: @CfSaferBirths, Dr Bill Kirkup, @CareQualityComm @TeamCMidO and @NHSEngland

Asked about face to face versus digital communications in the NHS, @matthancock says we need to learn with an open mind from how things have been done during the pandemic to identify what can be done using technology and what must return to being done face to face.
@MattHancock says he "very much hopes" that the Healthcare Safety Investigation Branch Bill will be brought in the next year.

Asked about parents' access to babies in neonatal units during the pandemic, @MattHancock says he has taken this up with the NHS and will write to the Committee within a fortnight with a progress update.
@MattHancock says his most important message on mental health is: there is help, and people should ask for it.

Asked about mental health support for children affected by lockdown, @MattHancock acknowledges the importance of the issue and says the fastest funding increases in the NHS are coming in children's mental health, and we need to improve access services and support in schools.
Asked about local lockdowns, @MattHancock says that support for people to self-isolate in lockdown areas has been put in place, and contact tracing works seamlessly across national and local teams.

@MattHancock says there is a policy that people should not have to travel more than 75 miles for a #COVID19 test and says he has not heard any evidence of this happening since it was put in place, but he acknowledges operational challenges with an increase in demand for testing.

@MattHancock says all of us must take the current spike in coronavirus infection rates very seriously indeed. He wants us all to be able to enjoy the kind of Christmas we all yearn for but that will take effort from us all - hands, face, space.

Talking about elective surgery, @MattHancock says in England the goal is to reach 95% of normal over the Autumn. In many areas we have nearly got back to normal. In those areas with aerosol-generating procedures it's harder. Testing and infection control measures will help.

@MattHancock says reassuring patients and the public will be an option using rapid turnaround, next-generation tests in huge quantities when available. Referencing current testing challenges, he says operational challenges will be resolved "in the coming weeks"

@MattHancock says a lesson we have learnt from covid which applies throughout the NHS is that we have not had enough focus on diagnostics and far too much on patching things up later. This was the case for covid and is true for other infectious disease, and for cancer diagnostics

@MattHancock says we don't yet know how many excess cancer deaths may end up being caused by #COVID19 as it depends on getting through the backlog. He says we are making progress and the number of people waiting more than 62 days for cancer diagnosis & treatment has halved.

Responding to testimony from a cancer patient, @MattHancock says that some treatments - on clinical advice - were not appropriate during a pandemic and had to be delayed. The policy was that each patient was communicated with individually.

@MattHancock acknowledges consequences of long covid and says long-term impacts can be debilitating even if initial illness wasn't severe. He says it's important to remember as infections rise among young people. He offers to ensure GPs know they can refer to long covid clinics.
@MattHancock tells us that per head of the population we have one of the biggest testing systems in the world, and very sophisticated contact tracing.

A second coronavirus wave isn't inevitable says @MattHancock - it depends on the actions we take. The first line of defence is social distancing. The next line of defence is testing and tracing which is radically stronger than in March. Local action is the third line of defence.

Asked about delays to bringing forward social care reform, @MattHancock says the Government made clear manifesto commitments on social care, but obviously coronavirus has delayed longer-term reform. Internal discussions on reform have picked up again, he says.

@MattHancock says there is a case for a more integrated approach to training and employment across health and social care. He says he would love to make it easier for a nurse to move between working in the NHS and working in social care.

@MattHancock says that the health and care visa will extend to people with a registered qualification working in social care. He says he does not think the Immigration Bill will undermine parity between NHS and social care professionals.

@MattHancock recognises the pressures in social care - demographic challenges, pressure on the delivery of care in the short-term, and long-term funding reform. He says he is in the depths of a spending review discussion and will share work done so far.
@MattHancock tells us the current way the social care system operates clearly has embedded in it a series of injustices that have grown up over time.

@MattHancock recognises the powerful videos from social care users capture the challenge we face as a society in finding long term reform for social care ‚Äì high bills and costs, plus extra demands and needs above that for which the state provides.
The Chair @Jeremy_Hunt begins by thanking @MattHancock and particularly the staff at @DHSCgovuk for their efforts during the pandemic.

‚è≥ We are now questioning the Secretary of State @MattHancock on the second half of today‚Äôs session on social care: funding and workforce. 

üì∫ Watch live: https://t.co/xmO0yHvrEr

Continue following this thread for live tweets üëáüèø

Social care is not an island says Sarah Pickup @LGAComms. It has to link to the NHS but also to housing, leisure and public health services. All of those services are critical and need a multi-year funding settlement along with social care.

James Bullion @1adass calls for a social care workforce strategy and a National Care Wage of ¬£10.90 per hour, linked to a band 3 NHS healthcare assistant - the median social care wage in 2019 was ¬£8.10 per hour.

People are the best determinants of what should be commissioned on their behalf says James Bullion @1adass. In commissioning homecare we have been far too transactional and don't have an outcomes-based approach.

Sarah Pickup @LGAComms acknowledges local authority commissioning of social care has been mixed, but says resource and capacity constraints don't lead to ideal commissioning and that local authority commissioning at its best is really good at partnership working in communities.

About a third of social care providers are estimated by @1adass to be making a loss, and that may rise. The ¬£3.2bn allocated to local government has enabled councils to assist providers but most councils are reaching the end of the pot - just as winter is approaching.

We've had a nearly 6% reduction in the number of people being looked after by local authorities, who have been forced to prioritise. People are being left to fend for themselves and there are around 1.5-2 million people with unmet need or under-met need, says @1adass.

In the last ten years social care budgets have risen by 16.5% says @LGAcomms, but inflation and demographic changes have risen by 28.3%. Clearly, demand for social care exceeds supply, so the only thing you can do is prioritise and ration.

We don't want a short-term solution to be a substitute for a serious announcement about getting on with reform in social care, says @LGAcomms. Social care needs funding so that people can live their lives in the way they want to.

We fear that without further investment is on the brink of collapse, says @1adass. The Chancellor needs to address immediate pressures in local authorities and the social care sector, and make a commitment to long-term reform and funding.

Our session on social care: funding and workforce with Secretary of State @MattHancock, @1adass and @LGAcomms has now started.

üî¨ Yesterday we questioned @CMO_England on the management of #coronavirus, including test and trace.

He told us the decision to stop community testing in March was "entirely practical" due to constrained testing capacity.

üì∫ Watch the full session: https://t.co/LzVoGKX0ic https://t.co/eMTghPQqia

Our session on the management of #coronavirus has ended 

Thank you to all our witnesses @CMO_England, Dr Jenny Harries, @JeremyFarrar, @devisridhar, Prof Sir John Bell, Prof Sir Paul Nurse & Prof Jonathan Van-Tam

üíª Rewatch the session https://t.co/LzVoGKX0ic

Clicküîîfor more https://t.co/Jjil2VP0t0
@CMO_England says we are very lucky to have outstanding Directors of Public Health in this country and that more data is now being shared with local authorities at postcode level
Professor Van-Tam says he is more optimistic about getting a vaccine this side of Christmas but we won't have data on how it can be safely staged with the flu vaccine
@CMO_England says that we are very excited by and proud of the UK's vaccine work - but no one should be under any illusions: the chances of us getting a vaccine before Christmas are very low.

Asked about vaccination, Jonathan Van-Tam says we may get a vaccine targeted at a particular population. Vaccine effectiveness varies, targeting a relatively small proportion at the very highest risk will deal with those who have the risk loaded against them at the moment.

@CMO_England says the way @PHE_uk measures deaths did not make his job more difficult - he states that all ways of measuring deaths are flawed - the key thing is to do it systematically to establish a trend line

On data about deaths during the pandemic, @CMO_England says the metric that really matters at the end of the day is excess mortality, because it catches impacts that are both direct and indirect from Covid-19

Asked about testing and tracing community infections, @CMO_England states that we were so far away from having the infrastructure needed to deliver it at scale that fundamentally there was no possibility of achieving test, trace and isolate in March

On care home deaths, @CMO_England says his enthusiasm for blaming people is zero. He says every country with a care sector has not handled this well. In retrospect, the impact of those working in multiple homes, or not being given paid sick leave, were not taken into account.

Asked about the make up of SAGE, @CMO_England says there were certainly members of SAGE who have an understanding of the social care sector, and there were other routes for people in social care to give advice

@CMO_England says that at this point in time, our PPE supply lines are now much more secure - but if we have a major surge in the winter that is simultaneous with other countries, it would be foolish to say that the risk has gone away

Discussing scientific advice, @CMO_England says there was a complicated debate over the guidance on mass gatherings because of the risk of people congregating in other places, e.g. pubs. On face masks, he says the scientific consensus has changed, not just in the UK

Jenny Harries agrees that highlighting the principles behind guidance will help people to take forward guidance in what they do, because it's impossible to have guidance that will dictate every move that you make during the day

We need to know more about how frequently to routinely test NHS staff - if there was a big surge, I would be in favour of going ahead but given where we are with knowledge and capacity, it is better to do surveillance and continue with studies says @CMO_England
On NHS staff testing, @CMO_England says we would be at the margins of capacity if we were to do routine NHS staff testing even now, but that this is improving
Given the capacity we had, @CMO_England says he continues to believe that the advice to stop community testing was the right one. The decision was entirely practical.

@CMO_England says SAGE was consistent in saying we needed considerably more testing capacity, but test, trace and isolate requires more than just testing capacity and we did not have the infrastructure - you cannot suddenly switch these things on

@CMO_England says that other countries put more emphasis on the case isolation. That was possible for the UK to do in the early stages, but not later on. When the wave came from Europe we did not have capacity for the scale of testing, case finding and isolation needed.

@CMO_England agrees with previous witnesses that the UK under-invested in public health - he says that every time there's a crisis, we say that more investment is needed, and then memory fades. There is a continued issue of investment.

Asked about the timing of lockdown, @CMO_England states that he is confident that ministers at the time followed the advice given by SAGE with a delay that was no more than you would reasonably expect given the difficulty of the situation.

We are now questioning our second panel of witnesses ‚Äì 
@CMO_England
 Professor Chris Whitty, Dr Jenny Harries and Professor Jonathan Van-Tam.

Television Watch live: https://t.co/LzVoGKX0ic

Follow for more live tweetsüëáüèø
Our first panel has now concluded. Thank you to our witnesses, @devisridhar, @JeremyFarrar, Professor Sir John Bell and Professor Sir Paul Nurse, for their contributions. https://t.co/cDpgRuFzuu

On vaccines, Professor Sir John Bell says the reality is that this pathogen is here forever. The vaccine is unlikely to have a durable effect so we will have a continual cycle of vaccinations and more disease. The idea that we will eliminate coronavirus completely is unrealistic

Professor Sir John Bell and @jeremyfarrar agree that while there may be some natural immunity in people who recovered from SARS, public health systems are more important. Remarkable success in Vietnam has more to do with a very strong public health system

On care homes, @devisridhar says to protect the social care sector we have to keep transmission low, rigorously test and screen, and make clear decision-making structures and policies. What has happened in care homes is a tragedy.

@JeremyFarrar says there is no doubt that overweight and obesity is a risk factor for more severe Covid-19 outcomes, and that it is a clear risk factor for other conditions, and that Government policy to encourage more healthy lifestyles is important

@devisridhar says if you want to reassure people, you have to provide them with accurate data and explain it. The way to get trust is not just to tell people they will be safe, but to show them data. Not having any data is as bad a problem as publishing data that needs explaining

There is definitely a lack of diversity in SAGE, and I don't think it's a good decision making forum, says Professor Sir Paul Nurse. In dealing with crises of this sort we need a multidisciplinary approach, and we need to be better practised at working together

Professor Sir Paul Nurse outlines what we need to put in place before the autumn:
- Clear leadership "without people passing the buck"
- Communication and maintaining trust
- Testing capacity - with a better locally-connected lab system, not just centralised lighthouse labs

@JeremyFarrar says #shielding is particularly difficult and we should not underestimate the impact of isolation on the people asked to shield. There is no zero risk situation but with hand washing, face masks, physical distancing of one or two metres people can meet safely

This infection is not going away and we will not be done by Christmas, says @JeremyFarrar - even with a vaccine or effective treatments, humanity will be living with this virus for decades to come and we need a consistent, long-term approach

On communications, @JeremyFarrar says that consistent messaging, and trust in that messaging, is vital. The public have to trust the message and the messenger, and that message has to be consistent over time. He says this has been more consistent in Scotland

@devisridhar says the 13 March SAGE minutes suggest that full suppression was undesirable as it would risk a second peak. What that decision missed was that the science would deliver solutions later on - and that you can achieve national elimination with border control
Sir John Bell says there is "no doubt" that if the UK had locked down earlier, we would have had a better effect from the lockdown
.@JeremyFarrar says he doesn't believe anyone could have been arguing from a scientific or public health perspective for herd immunity. He says he does not believe SAGE ever advised that.

.@JeremyFarrar says you need to be faster than the epidemic, which is why public health is so vital. Systems need to be in place before you need them. We need to use these three months wisely or we will face a very difficult winter
Sir John Bell says "Shame on us" that we were asleep to the concept that we would have a pandemic. We had 8 possible pandemics in recent years and we should have recognised it.

Lockdowns are very blunt and a measure of last resort, says @devisridhar, and as we've seen in Serbia there have been mass riots. We should be using summer to really push down infections to help us survive winter.

The decision to abandon containment was quite dangerous says @devisridhar, given uncertainty about immunity, long-term health issues - and given we had learnt so much about how you can successfully contain #coronavirus

@devisridhar tells us there was a playbook as to how to control #coronavirus early on - you could already see by February that South Korea was managing the situation by extensive testing and tracing, isolating carriers, face coverings and distancing, travel restrictions

It wasn't a novelty to think that we should test healthcare workers, we had already learnt that from other countries, says Sir John Bell - as time went on, there was a suspicion that NHS institutions were avoiding testing so they didn't lose their workforce. That is not ethical.

Professor Sir John Bell agrees: "The failure to address healthcare testing was a major oversight, and one where I'm not entirely sure what the motives were... as the number of cases rose, NHS lab capacity was completely overwhelmed and PHE were totally out of their depth"

Professor Sir Paul Nurse says research suggests that up to 45% of healthcare workers were infected during the peak of #coronavirus, yet none of them were being tested, including people without symptoms. "This is a major failure... healthcare workers deserve better"

For example, Professor Sir Paul Nurse says that the decision to invest in large lighthouse laboratories, thinking that they would be delivered in time to help with the pandemic, was "clearly a big mistake" but says he has "no idea" who made the decision

.@JeremyFarrar tells us he regrets that SAGE was not more blunt and robust in its advice, but that its job was not to hold people to account. Professor Sir Paul Nurse says there has been too much "pass the parcel" and it hasn't always been clear who is in charge of the strategy

January and February were the two critical months, says @JeremyFarrar. On test and trace he says that we had a limited number of tests, and there was a concern about the level of community transmission - but in hindsight, it was a mistake not to ramp up the number of tests

.@JeremyFarrar says that public health can't just be turned on and off. It needs long-term investment, but has been neglected globally, including in the UK - we let down our guard and didn‚Äôt realise the power of infectious diseases

STARTING NOW: Our session on the management of #coronavirus

Welcome to our first panel - Professor Sir John Bell, Professor Sir Paul Nurse, Professor @devisridhar and Professor Sir @JeremyFarrar

Sir Andrew Dilnot ends by recalling the experiences of Pamela, Deborah, and Kevin - you could multiply those thousands, hundreds of thousands of times. There's an opportunity here to do something really good... let's just do it. #socialcare
Sir Andrew Dilnot says he would now set ‚Äòhotel costs‚Äô at the rate of the state pension ‚Äì about ¬£8,000 per year #socialcare
Sir Andrew Dilnot calls for a change in society's attitudes towards old age, towards disability, and towards those who are caring for these people. We need to celebrate ageing and celebrate caring.

The care market is like being in a shop with no prices. That makes it very hard as a provider to innovate, adds Sir Andrew Dilnot. The funding model creates unfairness and anxiety for individuals, but also makes it difficult for #socialcare providers and contributes to low wages.
¬£45,000 would be an appropriate level for a cap on #socialcare costs, and would cost the state ¬£3.1bn a year, says Sir Andrew Dilnot.

Free personal care would be a bit like saying let‚Äôs make GP services free, but leaving those who have cancer exposed to risk, says Sir Andrew. Those facing very substantial costs would still be very exposed. The people we want to help most are those who face the highest needs.

A cap on #socialcare costs protects those who are the unluckiest with the highest care needs, says Sir Andrew Dilnot. Beyond the level of the cap, the state steps in and is able to cover catastrophic costs. A cap takes away fear.

Sir Andrew Dilnot sets out that the first essential step is to put more money into the means-tested system. Then we need to reform the means-tested system, which currently leaves people facing a huge cliff edge.

Sir Andrew Dilnot tells the Committee that we just don't spend enough on care. We want to be a society that looks after people, but the current means-tested system ‚Äì staffed by wonderful people doing great work - is so underfunded that it is a stain on our country.
In order to tackle the #socialcare workforce shortage in Japan more carers are being recruited from outside Japan, says @yasu_shio.

‚ñ∂Ô∏è Earlier in this session on #socialcare, we heard from Kevin Caulfield about the financial challenges facing disabled people: 
https://t.co/FdmWchZn2E https://t.co/W2fZaayQW6

@yasu_shio says that the care burden on families has decreased significantly in Japan, with more efficiency and choice in the market. Every three years the fee schedule is reviewed, adding flexibility. Financial sustainability remains a challenge, as does a shortage of carers.

@yasu_shio outlines Japan's 2000 #socialcare reforms, expanding affordable and accessible care services, and giving people a choice. Individuals pay 10% of care costs and the Government covers the rest. Tax and premiums raise the funds, and all citizens over 40 pay the premium.

Lord Forsyth, Chair @LordsEconCom, is thanked by Health and Social Care Committee Chair @Jeremy_hunt for his evidence on #socialcare this morning. We will now hear from Sir Andrew Dilnot and Yasuhisa Shiozaki @yasu_shio.

üì∫Watch here: https://t.co/UNCc1Z7Sfn

Cross party consensus for social care reform does exist, argues Lord Forsyth. @LordsEconCom‚Äôs report was welcomed on both sides of the House of Lords and Commons, with funding the only sticking point. Reform is expensive, but politics should reach out to the most vulnerable.

Lord Forsyth @LordsEconCom says the system is grossly underfunded, unfair, and undervalues carers. We need to put right the money that has been taken out of social care, and deal with the unfairness that if you have dementia or motor neurone disease you get no free #socialcare.

Lord Forsyth outlines the ‚Äúfalse distinction‚Äù in #socialcare. He believes in the health service principles that care should be delivered free at the point of use to those who need it, and does not understand why motor neurone disease is not treated in the same way as cancer.

Chair @Jeremy_Hunt thanks Kevin Caulfield, Pamela King and Deborah Gray @wordswork on behalf of the Committee for sharing their experiences of the #socialcare system. 

Our next witness will be Lord Forsyth of Drumlean, Chair @LordsEconCom. 

üì∫Watch: https://t.co/UNCc1Zpt6V
Asked what message she would like the Government to take away from the experience of lockdown, Deborah @wordswork says it is that #socialcare workers are skilled professionals.

Deborah @wordswork was 55 when her husband was diagnosed with Alzheimer's, and worried she might have to sell her home to fund his care. This was one burden too far in light of the fact she had given up her job to care for him, which had an impact on her own financial future.

Deborah @wordswork describes being told her husband's dementia is not a 'primary health care need'. Information on funding is confusing, hard to find, and contradictory. It is impossible to plan ahead, costing many sleepless nights. Navigating the system adds to Deborah‚Äôs stress.
Kevin outlines the barriers that charging creates for disabled people. In his view, it cannot be acceptable in the 21st century that people are falling into debt to pay for the care they need.

Kevin Caulfield describes a demeaning #socialcare financial assessment process, when what people need is support, peace and tranquillity. Instead, navigating the system places burdens on you as an individual, and reinforces the feeling of being 'other', and a burden.

As Diana‚Äôs savings fell below the eligibility threshold, her sister and brother, both pensioners, were asked to pay top up fees. They couldn‚Äôt, so Diana's case was heard by a local authority review board, to determine whether she would be able to stay on in her current care home.

Describing her struggle to find suitable care for her sister after her stroke, Pamela King says she was advised not to find somewhere too expensive, because social services would ask her to move Diana out into a cheaper home when her funds ran out.

The Health and Social Care Committee‚Äôs session on #socialcare funding and workforce has now begun.

Simon Stevens notes the work of the Committee in the last Parliament on this subject, and the importance of the announcement to families of cystic fibrosis patients up and down the country @cftrust.

See more about the Committee's previous work here: https://t.co/fNa6KsVclp

Simon Stevens closes the session by telling the Committee that this morning @NHSEngland has signed a commercial agreement with @VertexPharma to make available its triple therapy for cystic fibrosis patients--on the very day it receives its European licence

SP also emphasises the very important, ongoing role that charities are playing in supporting patients and the NHS and care sector through the pandemic, referencing in particular members of @RichmondGroup14
Simon Stevens tells the Committee that the last clap for carers on Sunday is also an opportunity to thank care staff, volunteers, bus and train drivers, and those keeping food on our shelves.

There is complete acceptance now that there needs to be a beefed up programme of support for social care, Simon Stevens continues, but I do not accept that the NHS was wrong to mobilise itself for a huge increase in people needing hospital care as a result of COVID

The pandemic has shone a spotlight onto lack of funding and resilience in the social care sector, observes Simon Stevens, in response to questioning from @KeeleyMP. Care providers should be properly funded for the enhanced duties they have taken on during the pandemic, he says

.@NHSEnglandNMD goes on to say that @NHSEngland would like to build on the lessons learnt from the pandemic and that in the event of a second wave the NHS would seek to manage in a way that would avoid having to stand down routine services

Cttee member Laura Trott asks about planning for a second wave. @NHSEnglandNMD notes that we're beginning to see localised outbreaks, and need to ensure that local health systems, working with local public health teams and local authorities, are well connected and able to respond

Dr Katherine Henderson @RCollEM previously told us that a "beefed-up 111 call service" would help ensure those that do and don't need A&E care could be more efficiently triaged. @NHSEnglandNMD confirms to us that various versions of this are now being tested
The NHS has always relied on a diverse workforce, and we need to get better at supporting them, Simon Stevens tells the Committee

.@NHSEnglandNMD says @NHSEngland has developed a risk assessment framework for employers to go through with individual members of staff and make necessary adjustments e.g. redeployment, working from home
Questioned by Committee member @SarahOwen_, @NHSEnglandNMD agrees that it is absolutely critical to support BAME staff due to increased COVID risk.

PPE supply is in a better place than it was a few months ago, says @NHSEnglandNMD. We have more confidence in our supplies, but it is important that we get ahead in terms of the amount of PPE that is required going into winter
The aim is by the end of September to have significant additional testing capacity so that testing of asymptomatic NHS staff can be increased, if necessary, Simon Stevens tells the Committee.

Decisions on testing--who should be tested and how frequently--have been led by @CMO_England, says Simon Stevens. We do, however, want to see a significant increase in staff testing capacity and the clear intention is to substantially expand testing.
Questioning moves on to testing of NHS staff. @NHSEnglandNMD says that @CMO_England would say we don‚Äôt have the evidence base to know with what frequency staff should be tested

We have given a very clear message to the NHS to give infection control training to care homes and to bring forward the enhanced care in care homes package so that every care home has a named clinical lead in primary care, says @AKPritchard2
.@NHSEnglandNMD does not accept that the NHS took its eye off the ball in relation to infection prevention within health and care settings

Prof Powis @NHSEnglandNMD says it is difficult to say with hindsight whether advice should have been different in early March, but points out that regular testing is now being done for patients discharged to care homes

Chair @Jeremy_Hunt challenges witnesses on discharge of patients to care homes. Simon Stevens says there was an absolute necessity for hospitals to deal with the sharp increase in coronavirus patients (around 2 million people) and only 2.8% who left hospitals went to care homes

The support put in place for our staff during this period has to be the new normal, says Simon Stevens. @AKPritchard2  says it has been the most unbelievably difficult period for staff but the response has been remarkable, and commits to maintaining the support offer for staff
We are working closely with @TheBDA to help them balance safety and activity, including PPE costs, adds @AKPritchard2

.@rosie4westlancs asks about dentistry: We have maintained a rollover contract model for NHS dentists so that there is stability and a reliable source of income separated from the amount of activity being done at the moment, says @AKPritchard2

Simon Stevens responds to clips of our previous witnesses Rob Martinez and @dalonic speaking about their experience as non-Covid patients in the pandemic: communication is key and hospital teams have a big job of work to communicate with patients whose care has been disrupted

Simon Stevens responds to clips of our earlier witnesses Rob Martinez and @dalonic speaking about their experience as non-Covid patients: he says communication is key and hospital teams have a big job of work to do to communicate with patients whose care has been disrupted

We're hearing from Sir Simon Stevens, Chief Executive of @NHSEngland, National Medical Director Prof Steve Powis @NHSEnglandNMD and Chief Operating Officer Amanda Pritchard @AKPritchard2 https://t.co/gYOOlqjASF
During the March, April and May period, hospital resources were treating over 100,000 coronavirus inpatients, the Committee is told
Fewer people are coming forward so overall the waiting list is down by half a million, but it will go up quite significantly as people start returning to the NHS, says Simon Stevens

Simon Stevens says the NHS had 725,000 fewer hospital admissions in March and April based on pre-COVID levels, with the greatest drop in April, but that number has begun to recover to around 55% of pre-Covid levels and going into July and August we are on track for it to be 75%
Now we move on to our second panel: Sir Simon Stevens, Chief Executive of @NHSEngland, Prof Stephen Powis @NHSEnglandNMD and Amanda Pritchard @AKPritchard2 , Chief Operating Officer

We knew we were short of staff before COVID, and historically the UK has relied on other countries, observes @bodgoddard. One of the challenges of COVID is that people are less likely to want to or be able to travel. We are reliant on @ukhomeoffice to improve mobility

We need an honest and difficult debate about priorities ‚Äì pain, quality of life, criticality in terms of life ‚Äì to tackle the huge backlog, @ChrisCEOHopson repeats, and some national guidance from @NHSEngland about how that will be done

Doctors are even more worried than @ChrisCEOHopson's members, says @bodgoddard - 70% of people don't think we'll be back to where we need to be in 12 months' time, and 39% think it'll be longer than 18 months

.@ChrisCEOHopson tells Chair @Jeremy_Hunt: you're right to identify that if we want to reach that absolute gold standard then we should be heading towards regular testing of staff, and we need to get there as quickly as possible

Responding to a question about testing of NHS staff, @ChrisCEOHopson suggests that the real reason we‚Äôre not doing testing of staff is that there doesn‚Äôt seem to be capacity. We need a clear picture of when that is going to come and how that‚Äôs going to be built up, he warns.
There is a growing gap in demand which we will not be able to fully close, argues @ChrisCEOHopson - we need a mature debate about what the priorities are for the NHS
Hospitals are currently working to tackle the backlog of healthcare demand that has grown during the pandemic, but with a 20-40% reduced capacity, says @ChrisCEOHopson

Yesterday our #socialcare session explored the issues facing people working in social care.

One thing the Committee heard strongly was how little professional recognition care workers get. Listen to @mellydust describe what it's like:

üì∫Full session https://t.co/HWYokEddsb https://t.co/v8j8fxGF8v

@socfuture @ASCAPPG @Jeremy_Hunt @ProfMartinGreen @CareEngland @oonaghsmyth @skillsforcare @drjanetownson @ukhca Hi, thank you for this important feedback. Today's session focused on the social care workforce and prioritised the voices of those who themselves work in social care, but the principle of listening to people with lived experiences continues to be very important to the Committee.

Our session on Social care: funding and workforce has now ended. We thank our witnesses - @CareEngland, @skillsforcare, @ukhca, @Agincare, @mellydust, @auburn_mere and Priscilla Wakefield House Nursing Home. 
¬†
üíªWatch the session back here: https://t.co/yy5kSKedgJ

Around 17% of social care workers are not British & the current social care salary is lower than the earnings threshold under current migration policy plans, says @oonaghsmyth. @drjanetownson also recommends that social care should be added to the shortage occupation list.

We need to change the narrative around care to make sure people see it as a valued and respected profession - it is significant contributor to the economy, says @oonaghsmyth. This, again, highlights to us the perception of social care workers and the need to recognise their work.

He adds:  The care home may also be able to play a big role in helping deal with the backlog in elective procedures, by providing quick access to reablement care (i.e. supporting individuals post-surgery)

@ProfMartinGreen: Changes to the hospital discharge process - where people are discharged and then assessed afterwards - have been very helpful and will continue to be beneficial as we begin to face winter pressures.

@drjanetownson says: Councils are monopsony purchasers and they effectively coerce providers into providing care at a minimum price. This is not the right answer, and it is the workforce, and the people who receive care, who suffer.

He adds: "If there is going to be localism, there should be justification for it, rather than it just been a laissez-faire approach from politicians". While other witnesses have told us "the current approach simply isn't good enough".

There is a vastly disproportionate spread of money between health and social care, says @ProfMartinGreen - commissioning is all about transactions, not about outcomes, not about incentivisation - we need a root and branch reform
@drjanetownson says that "We need to get away from a commissioning system that treats care workers - and the people they care for - as commodities" #socialcare

Some of the key issues involve registration schemes, funding & training for the social care sector. We've heard from witnesses that a registration scheme for care workers would bring benefits but adequate funding, training & proper workforce strategy needs to underpin this.

We believe the long-term goal for home care should be registration, says @drjanetownson , but this needs to be in the context of a whole set of other measures, such as workforce planning, development and training.

@oonaghsmyth reiterates some of the points we've heard from other witnesses this morning. In particular, she emphasises the lack of funding and support for care workers, highlighting that only "¬£7.72 is spent per head on training for social care staff" #socialcare

She adds: All the focus was on the NHS as an organisation, but it should have been on the most vulnerable citizens, bringing together... Very little testing has been made available for home care workers - it has all been directed at care homes.

@drjanetownson: at the start of the pandemic we saw people being discharged from hospitals without tests. Residents of care homes all have several underlying conditions and are at the highest risk. This didn't translate into a consistent approach - care homes weren't supported.

UK Parliament will hold a minute‚Äôs silence to remember the three people who were killed in the terror attack in Reading on Saturday at 11am today. Our session will consequently be suspended for a minute from 11am.

We need a conversation about what the state can deliver and what an individual should deliver, says @ProfMartinGreen, he says that the amount of ageism in our health system is very noticeable it is seen as the NHS has retreated from care homes leaving individuals on their own

@ProfMartinGreen If we were starting from scratch, we would have a more integrated system, taking housing, care &other services. A greater focus on prevention is also needed, & more power should be given to individuals to shape their own care according to what they need and want.

@drjanetownson tells us that "Nobody at local level had planned for pandemic of this level, PPE was diverted to the NHS and testing still isn't available for the home-care sector - we are at the bottom of the pile...we've been lucky to avoid too much of a catastrophe..."

@ProfMartinGreen says: the proposed salary threshold for immigration is going to have a significant effect - the Govt hasn't got their strategy right to make sure we have enough people in the pipeline. A transition plan to allow some staff to come from overseas is more sensible

Jane Townson @drjanetownson tells us "We don't have a social care strategy let alone workforce strategy...citizens want to stay at home and stay in communities and surrounded by the people that they love"

He adds: This should be about a salaried profession...Health Education England @NHS_HealthEdEng, who NHS oversee training and workforce, have a budget of ¬£4.7bn, compared to ¬£21mil for Skills for Care, the organisation responsible for social care training and workforce.

@ProfMartinGreen We don't see anything like the same recognition for social care workers and the work we do see for other NHS staff. This despite social care workers having to deal with the same patients. Yet, we talk about integration all the time.

@drjanetownson tells us that "We believe it should be illegal for councils to purchase care at rates below ¬£15 per hour, which does not enable providers to cover the minimum wage and the employment costs they face. Nearly 60% of home care workers are on zero hours contracts."

@drjanetownson says pay is a key factor. Local authorities pay home-care providers by the minute, which engenders a lack of trust. @oonaghsmyth similarly says that pay, recognition and development and support are the keys to stabilising the social care workforce #socialcare

@oonagh_smyth describes an experienced social care worker who hasn't had a day off in 7 weeks, trying to hold her service together, and says there is a real risk that experienced social care staff will suffer from PTSD and leave the service.
@oonagh_smyth tell the Committee: "Although the vacancy rate has fallen slightly during the pandemic, the absence rate during COVID has trebled."

We are now questioning our second panel of witnesses - @ProfMartinGreen of @CareEngland, @oonagh_smyth of @skillsforcare and @drjanetownson of @ukhca, for our session on Social care: funding and workforce.
