Chair @Jeremy_Hunt , on behalf of the Committee, thanks Sue Ann Balcombe @dally_park, Marlene Kelly @auburn_mere, Mel Cairnduff @mellydust and Raina Summerson @Agincare for their work in the social care sector & for sparing the time to discuss their experiences with the Committee
Raina Summerson @Agincare says: "If we try to do care on the cheap, we are not going to get a workforce that feels valued."

On the practical changes that could encourage people to work in care, Mel Cairnduff @mellydust responds that "carers need to know what they're coming into. You need to have a real understanding of what the job is."

Sue Ann Balcombe @dally_park¬†emphasises that the media has a huge role in securing recognition for the social care sector. On Thursdays we'd be clapping for the NHS, but where were the carers in this?
Raina says that "If we go back to the commissioning and purchasing behaviours of the past, it will be totally demoralising"

Raina Summerson @Agincare tell us that "Pay-by-minute calls make social care workers feel like they are not trusted. This has stopped during the pandemic because of necessity, but if we go back to that again that will be really demoralising."
She adds: Social care staff now need to be encouraged and supported and acknowledged for these responsibilities going forward.

Marlene Kelly says: Social care staff were entrusted with lots of responsibilities during the pandemic, including providing amazing end of life care. If these responsibilities are taken away again, that will be hugely demoralising.
@dally_park¬†says that "It's knowing the impact that one moment in time has for that individual - it swells your heart and you leave work knowing you've done your best"
@mellydust tells us "It's what I do for them, not what I do for the company I work for, or for myself. It's seeing the people I look after smile - that's what I do my job for."
You can also watch the session live here:  https://t.co/yy5kSKedgJ

We're hearing from social care staff and managers as part of our inquiry into "social care: funding and workforce". We've heard about staff not being valued and being overlooked. We've heard about poor co-ordination by Govt and other organisations. Follow for live tweets.

@mellydust: Domiciliary care is not a low skilled job. We administer controlled drugs and wound care, just as nurses do, but we don't get the recognition that they do. There are so many things that nurses used to do that we do, but we are still treated as unskilled workers.

We're hearing about problems with care workers getting the right recognition. Raina Summerson: "Awareness of home carers is so little, they face even less recognition but they make absolutely critical decisions, risk assessment, increasing medical tasks, supporting primary care"
Raina Summerson (@Agincare) similarly tells us: We have care workers being told they weren't key workers; there is a real lack of understanding about the critical role social care staff play.
She explains that people "don't understand what a domiciliary care worker does, we go to people's homes and we can't change uniforms like you can in a home".

Mel Cairnduff (@mellydust) tells us that she "feels valued by the company that I work for, but I don't feel valued by the public. It's been particularly tough during the pandemic. We get tutted at because we're in uniform out in the street...

Expanding on this, Marlene, says that it felt like every department was working independently. "There were points when I was receiving three calls a week from three different departments asking the same ten questions. It was such an incredible waste of time." #socialcare

Marlene also tell us that she felt like there was very poor co-ordination between different departments during the pandemic - I was being asked the same questions by multiple different agencies every day.
She says that "testing in a major issue - people were doing guesswork about whether people had died from Covid-19 in care homes".

Sue Ann says: We have not had access to testing and we have been doing guess work on whether our residents had died from Covid-19 - we need to be treated on the same level as the NHS. If there is a second wave, we needed to be treated on a par with NHS staff.

Marlene Kelly says: the home that I manage is a private home. We're able to pay the staff a higher rate than local authority homes - because of that most of my staff have done their 10 years. If they're valued, if they're paid well, they will stay.

Witnesses tell us: You have to compete, and we have had members of staff who leave because they can earn more in retail, with less responsibility. People still see social care as a job that anyone can walk into - but in fact most propel do this job because it's their vocation.

Sue Anne tells us: There is a lot of responsibility that care workers take on, but this is not reflected in the pay - we are unable to pay the London living wage, but the funding isn't there. #socialcare

Sue Ann Balcombe @dally_park¬†says: seeing the sheer amount of responsibility Registered Managers have, scares people away. The job of a Registered Manager can be very lonely if you don't have a support network of other managers. If one thing goes wrong, you can end up in prison.
Marlene Kelly @auburn_mere continues: "I love my job, it's an amazing job and every day is completely different - but nobody really understands, it's like five people moulded into one"

People don't understand the care qualifications which are available: more professional qualifications should be available along the lines of NHS or social work qualifications. People don't know what a registered manager is. Social workers aren't recognised like other professions
Marlene continues to explain: after a 14 hr shift, we can't cut in queues. Although the care badge has been announced, it's still very difficult to get these.

Marlene Kelly (@auburn_mere) tells us that "at the weekend I saw an amazing sign saying '30% off' for all NHS workers bit it's really demoralising, when there are social care staff who have just come off 14 hour shifts and can't access the same benefits as other NHS staff...
Sue Ann Balcombe (@dally_park) tells us that the recognition that the NHS has is not seen in the social care sector. She tells us "We are seen as the underdogs, or the Cinderellas..."

Care workers giving evidence to Committee describe how they entered the profession because they have always loved caring, giving back to society and "making sure that every single day we bring a smile to their faces"

Our session on Social care: funding and workforce has started.

Finally, thank you to @VersusArthritis and @macmillancancer for helping us to highlight the voices of people most affected by the pandemic

Thank you as well to @dalonic, @CharlotteAugst, Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE and @LaylaMcCay who spoke to the Committee about the impact of #coronavirus on people living with cancer, on mental health services and the way the NHS as a whole works https://t.co/jJvQXW2FcG

Our session on core NHS and care services during the pandemic has now finished. 

Thank you to our first panel - Rob Martinez, @KatherineRCEM, Derek Alderson @RCSnews and @MickArmstrong61 who described the impact of #coronavirus on surgery, emergency departments and dentists https://t.co/gymB8qgZys
I am supposed to be shielding, but the advice is totally impossible to follow and is utterly meaningless, causing an enormous amount of distress says @dalonic
@CharlotteAugst says that difficulties caused for people by shielding are massive and have been exacerbated by the lack of clarity and communication of decision making

What have we learnt from Covid? How are we now going to change the conversation? How can we improve the way that the NHS works? - Key questions being considered by @NHSConfed from workforce to mental health to regulation

We don't just want to return to the old ways of working - there's an opportunity to think about how we plan, how we commission, how we deliver care in new, more effective and more productive ways @LaylaMcCay @NHSConfed

We have heard that trusts and CCGs are doing things in a few weeks that would otherwise have taken years to accomplish, says @LaylaMcCay @NHSConfed. Having now tried out digital and seeing that it works, it's really moved things forward.

1.9m households don't have access to the internet, 25m people are on expensive pay-as-you-go tariffs says @CharlotteAugst - you need money and confidence to make telemedicine work. We need to tailor our technology responses to pick up people with the biggest needs

You have people who are socially isolated or don't have internet access, and we have to cater for those whilst continuing to reduce the need for face-to-face appointments where we can says Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE on remote consultations

People need to know why appointments are being cancelled and what is being done for them says Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE - this is not just an administrative matter, people need to be treated as individuals

The approach taken to talking to patients and public is very unsophisticated says @CharlotteAugst What happens in hospitals is only a small part of how we will weather this storm going into winter - patients and public are the most important actors and need tailored communication
On communication with patients, @CharlotteAugst thinks poor communication is the common thread through the patient stories we've heard - but this is not new in the NHS
Our members are telling us that pre-Covid-19, most people were working around 90% or more of capacity, and they are now expecting to be working at 60% says @LaylaMcCay @NHSConfed
The CQC inspection system has been very effective at putting quality and safety at the heart of the NHS, says Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE, and I would be concerned if inspections did not resume

Patient safety appears to have been taking a back seat, not in relation to the pandemic itself, but in an understandable rush to change things around, patient safety hasn't been properly considered, says Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE

People who need treatment are not being involved enough in decisions about what is happening next, says Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE . There is not enough explanation being provided to them and patients are not being considered holistically.

@CharlotteAugst says this is typical of people trying to access health services during the pandemic - in cancer there are 12,000 fewer patients receiving surgery, 6,000 fewer receiving chemotherapy, and 2,800 fewer receiving radiotherapy
@dalonic: I'm a single mum with teenagers at home. My priority is to stay alive. I can't tell you how difficult that limbo period has been - but it has been resolved now

@dalonic: I started the lockdown in a clinical trial. I was told I needed chemotherapy but for most of the lockdown I have been sitting here, knowing my tumours were growing, with no word from the hospital about when treatment might start

Our second panel on core NHS and care services during the pandemic is starting now - we'll hear from @dalonic, @CharlotteAugst, Sir Robert Francis @HealthwatchE, and @LaylaMcCay @NHSConfed

üì∫: https://t.co/CENcsErLUs
Keep following our tweets üëáüèø
Pre-COVID you could protect a patient and it cost two or three pounds. Now it costs over forty pounds per patient. So dentists have huge expenses but very little income @MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA

The profession is ready and willing and very able to deliver says @MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA but we need a plan, we need clear lines of communication - and influence. If we need something and ask for it we expect to be heard

We got one working day's notice before we were told to open says @MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA. There was a plan for dentistry ready to go for a week before it was released, but it appears the political will and 'the system' yet again got in the way

@MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA: The Department of Health understands very well where we're coming from, it's the Treasury which seems to be the problem. We remain the Cinderella service of the NHS and it has to change.

@MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA: There is a serious concern that dentists won't be paid enough to keep going. It is financially nonviable to keep doing dentistry in small numbers - we need long term investment.
@MickArmstrong61 says private dental practices and NHS practices are on the brink, only 8% of practices think they're financially viable

@KatherineRCEM: We need emergency cases to come back and we need to get the balance right. Some patients who really need to aren't coming. But we're seeing people presenting as intoxicated going back up - I want to see the person who is having a stroke or having a heart attack.
The need to keep people safe has given us the opportunity to break down barriers. The demise of silo working has been one of the most positive things that has come out of this @KatherineRCEM

There must be no return to silo working, says @KatherineRCEM, and although training has suffered, we have managed to deliver a lot of teaching and training, embracing Zoom as a way of doing meetings. We can trust healthcare staff to do things from home.
If you have departments that are big enough, a workforce that is big enough, and are not overwhelmed by patients, then you can provide really effective care says @KatherineRCEM

@KatherineRCEM says integrated care is key to managing patient demand where patients could use a "beefed up" 111 call system. Technology is important to this, for example, we need to better track patients for example if they have followed the advice from 111

@KatherineRCEM Workforce is a real concern - we want to retain people, we want to make it possible to retain them in the system. We have a real worry about very experienced people for whom the aftermath (of the pandemic) might be too much.

@KatherineRCEM agrees - we can't build confidence in patients if we can't be sure that we can protect everybody. We need to sure risks around staff-on-staff infection and asymptomatic carriers of Covid-19 are minimised
It's absolutely essential to regain public confidence that we are able to test our staff regularly says Derek Alderson @RCSnews - pragmatically this should be at least twice weekly

We want people to have confidence that they can come to an emergency department with an emergency and be safe, says @KatherineRCEM, but we don't want people coming to ED where there are other places they could get their care

Derek Alderson @RCSnews warns it will certainly be many months and may even be several years before we fully catch up - says it's "completely unrealistic" to believe we can go at full speed very quickly

@MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA - we need the correct PPE consistently and widely available, but the protocols in place severely limit our capacity to treat patients - in our practice we'd normally offer 150 appointments a day, it's now 10-15
The effect on oral health has been "catastrophic" says @MickArmstrong61 @TheBDA - 8 million courses of treatment have been cancelled nationally

@MickArmstrong61 of @TheBDA describes how primary dental care has been "virtually non-existent" during the pandemic. Dentistry wasn't in a great place before the pandemic, he says - there were widening inequalities and rock-bottom morale and the pandemic has made it worse

@KatherineRCEM confirms that @RCEMpresident is calling for a "call before you walk" approach to emergency departments like in Scandinavian countries - but emphasises that 999 would remain and emergency depts would remain committed to being the safety net for patients

@KatherineRCEM describes the changes needed in emergency departments: the old way meant ED could never say "we're full" - we need space in ED for our most at-risk patients or there will be great pain and enormous harm. She suggests a better contact point for urgent care before ED
The Government needs to commit to maintaining such sites, including the arrangements with the private sector which have been taken during the pandemic, says Derek Alderson @RCSnews

The longer we are unable to restart scheduled services, the worse the situation is going to get says Derek Alderson @RCSnews - that's why we're calling to establish covid-light sites with minimal risk to patients

Derek Alderson @RCSnews says the big sadness is that Rob's story is not atypical - people waiting for joint replacements constitute one of the largest groups waiting unacceptably long times for their surgery - in April this year we saw 1 million fewer patients compared to 2019
Rob thanks @VersusArthritis for their support over the past 12 months - if you're affected by the issues he has raised you can call their helpline on 0800 5200 520 (Monday ‚Äì Friday, 9am ‚Äì 8pm)

The communication from hospitals has been really lacking and I just want to know what is happening, says Rob Martinez. The hospitals should have been in contact with people and given some update, rather than remaining totally silent.
I have had to give up my job, I have pain walking and sleeping, and no medication has helped whatsoever, says Rob Martinez. My life feels on hold and it's extremely frustrating.

My GP practice was working better during this pandemic than before it, says Rob Martinez, but I haven't heard from my local hospital since my operation was cancelled. I've now been told there is zero chance of my operation occuring this year.

Rob Martinez describes living with lymphoedema and needing two knee replacements - Rob is suffering severe pain but having waited since October 2019, his surgery that was planned for April has now been cancelled

Our first panel is starting now. We'll be hearing from @KatherineRCEM, @MickArmstrong61, @RCSnews, and Rob Martinez.

üá¨üáßHow do we spend on social care in the UK compared with Denmark? üá©üá∞

üó£Ô∏èListen to @AnitaCTHF from the @HealthFdn who estimated social care will need a further ¬£12bn by 2023/24 in yesterday's Committee session.

üíªWatch the full session: https://t.co/BIALRtKem2 https://t.co/m99U9KtWDU

ü´Ç The Committee heard @AnnaSeverwright describe the battle she faces to get #socialcare as someone in their 30s. 

‚ùìShe asked the key question - what are we funding for?
 
üì∫Catch up on the first session of our social care funding and workforce inquiry: https://t.co/BIALRtsDuu https://t.co/QN9QWA6QLX

In the last year of her life @DaphneHavercro1's mother Dorothy spent months in hospital when she should have been at home. The Committee heard Daphne's experience today in the first session of our #socialcare inquiry.

üì∫ Watch her full testimony: https://t.co/BIALRtsDuu https://t.co/p3JkefJdXu

Our hearing on Social care: funding and workforce has now ended. 

We thank our witnesses - @AnitaCTHF @AnnaSeverwright @TheIFS @DaphneHavercro1 Paul Little and Professor Tine Rosgaard. 

Watch it back here: https://t.co/BIALRtsDuu 
Check out our tweetsüëá
On average local authorities pay about ¬£17 per hour for home care - the UK Homecare Association estimate that the actual cost of delivering that care is ¬£21 per hour - says @AnitaCTHF

The local authority tells me I can't use my personal care funding to assist me with any health needs like picking up prescriptions or going to the GP - which is silly because if I don't, it will increase my need for social care in the future - says @AnnaSeverwright

@AnnaSeverwright describes the inequity she feels in that any inheritance from her family would be spent on social care, whereas other people her age who do not need social care would have the option of investing that money or using it for another purpose.

Purely hypothecated taxes give Government less flexibility; partially hypothecated taxes are another option, but there often a lack of transparency about how they are spent - @TheIFS suggests additional contributions from broad-based taxation would be more appropriate.

We need to recognise, accredit and develop the skills of those working in social care, as well as rewarding. Things like integrated training are likely more important than integrated budgets in terms of delivering care that feels integrated to those receiving it, says @AnitaCTHF
On the question of how you raise additional funding, there is a question of whether this is through general taxation, or a more ringfenced 'national insurance' style contribution, says @AnitaCTHF

The number of apprenticeships in social care fell by 50% last year - we need to make social care a career, consider whether it should be registered - the Gov't has committed to an NHS workforce strategy but there are no plans for a social care workforce strategy, says @AnitaCTHF
Both Houses of Parliament are holding a minute's silence in memory of George Floyd at 11am today. The committee joins this silence and is now suspended.

We have several issues to address with funding - access; quality; pay for the workforce; provider stability - says @AnitaCTHF - the way social care is funded is fundamentally unfair, and people face catastrophic care costs.

@TheIFS tell the committee: we have very little information on who receives social care, how it is paid for and what the outcomes of that are - that needs to change. @AnnaSeverwright says councils collect information on numbers, but not on the experiences behind those numbers.

We need increased funding to make this happen - but we need reform as well as funding. Because of the pressure to cut costs we have commodified social care, and contracting has been a race to the bottom says @AnitaCTHF

There is a gap between the vision set out in the Care Act - which aimed to put people at the heart of decisions about their care, and asks people what support they need to live the lives they want to live - and the reality says @AnitaCTHF

@AnitaCTHF tells the committee: you cannot have your cake and eat it - the costs we find ourselves facing are the consequences of success - longer life expectancy, increased female particpation in the labour market and other social changes.

@AnitaCTHF says that we spend just under 1.5% of GDP on social care. The ¬£12bn increase is a lot, but would only take us to 1.7% of GDP - way less than what Denmark spends, and only 0.2% of GDP increase.
@AnitaCTHF tells the committee that if we had kept at the access and quality of care provided in 2010, we'd be spending ¬£10bn more by 23/34, not ¬£3.9bn. Adding the living wage takes it to ¬£12bn.

Since 2015, the number of older people who need help has increased by 60,000, but the number of people who are getting help through the social care system has fallen by 40,000, says @AnitaCTHF - through funding constraints people who would need care are no longer getting it.

Regardless of whether you think the current funding levels deliver the sufficient quality and access to care, social care needs a further ¬£2bn per year by 2023/24 just to keep rise with population growth, says @AnitaCTHF

If we believe that older people, disabled people, people with learning disabilities, should be able to live as full a life as other people, then we need to be providing the funding that enables them to do that, says @AnnaSeverwright

I use direct payment to employ my own personal assistant carer, @AnnaSeverwright tells the committee - it means I get choice which is great, but the amount of money we get is very low, which means recruitment and retention of PAs is quite hard.

I feel sick when my funding review is due, as I fear that my funding will be cut - and I know many people who's funding has been cut by one third - that's a third less life they can live, says @AnnaSeverwright

@AnnaSeverwright tells the committee: I often have to choose how I use my social care allocation - if I only have two hours left this week, do I want to have a shower, do I want to go to shopping, do I want to meet a friend?

The structure and system for integrating health and social care doesn't matter to me as a social care user - what is important is that things are structured around me, as a person, to enable me to live the life I want to lead says @AnnaSeverwright

We are now hearing from our second panel of witnesses - @AnnaSeverwright @TheIFS @AnitaCTHF for our hearing on Social care: funding and workforce. 

 üì∫ Watch live here: https://t.co/BIALRtsDuu

Or follow us for more live tweetsüëá

In Denmark, both social care and health care assistants are working in hospitals and care settings, working across both sectors: training is a stepping stone, with progression from 'helpers' to 'assistants' and eventually becoming nurses if they wish, says Tine Rosgaard.

Wages have increased over the years, although they are not as high as other sectors, and the focus on reablement - work to improve older people's skills - is very rewarding for those working in social care, and leads to greater job satisfaction, says Tine Rosgaard.
Tine Rosgaard tells the committee that having somebody in hospital who understands the social care system is essential to the discharge team as they can act as a broker between the two systems.

We have a cultural difference in Nordic countries in that we regard personal care as a state responsibility - this is part of the social contract, care for frail older people is the responsibility of the local authority, says Tine Rosgaard.

If you can organise integrated support for people either at home or in a care home, which will support them in event of a crisis, that will not only prevent an unnecessary admission, but be a much better experience for the person in question, says Paul Little.

We try as much as we can in Denmark to provide social care at home, says Tine Rosgaard, provided free of charge - there is no stigma associated with using this service. There is a choice between providers, and around 11% of older people use home care.

Tine Rosgaard says reducing the number of LAs in Denmark increased efficiency, enabling us to establish routines and systems that promote integration between health and social care. Health and social care education and training is combined, and we focus on prevention.

The discharge process which we now have in place involves hospital based multidisciplinary teams including both primary and secondary care and social care professionals, says Tine Rosgaard, and this has improved discharge planning.

Asked whether she herself got any support as a carer, @DaphneHavercro1 says that although she asked for a carers assessment it never happened - and they did not follow it up as her priority was on getting her mother's care sorted.

Supporting my mother through the interface between health and social care was the most difficult thing I've faced in my life, says @DaphneHavercro1 - GPs have a key role to play in co-ordinating this, but the value that they can add is not being properly used.

@DaphneHavercro1 tells the committee: we found ourselves in what was really a dispute with the local authority about my mother's ability to make decisions and that seemed paralyse the care planning process - I was forced to write my own mother's care plan.

My mother needed to be listened to...she needed her family to be involved in planning the discharge...but it was almost like the health and social care professionals felt that they knew better, and we were side-lined, says @DaphneHavercro1

My mother needed to be listened to...she needed her family to be involved in planning the discharge...but it was almost like the health and social care professionals felt that they knew better, and we were side-lined, says @DaphneHavercro1

The priority of the hospital, community and social care teams was to spend as little money as possible on Dorothy, to keep her out of hospital, and to prevent inappropriate hospital admissions - it had the reverse effect, with three emergency admissions, says @DaphneHavercro1
There was no integrated working between health and social care professionals to plan discharge, and there was no continuity between clinicians, @DaphneHavercro1 tells the committee.

@DaphneHavercro1 describes how her mother, having waited in hospital for more than 7 months, finally had a care package agreed, but it was never implemented because of disputes about who should pay for it.

We are absolutely factoring in the recovery of every part of the NHS, as well as the potential of a second wave and the onset of winter in our #PPE demand modelling says Lord Deighton

At the beginning of this when we found ourselves desperately short of #PPE, we had 14,500 offers of support to provide supplies, says Lord Deighton. Sorting through these to identify how to fill gaps was a long and complicated process - we have something like 100 new suppliers
My plan is to build in more resilience to our supply plan here in the UK, to avoid reliance on particular other countries such as China, says Lord Deighton

We have now stabilised the #PPE situation to the degree that we are confident in our 7-day and 90-day horizon of supply and demand, says Lord Deighton, though there will be stresses from time to time https://t.co/YgbgwFkOZZ
The Committee is now moving on to question Lord Deighton about #PPE

.@didoharding: Testing capacity is ample for today but as we look towards winter where people have more flu like symptoms it will be important for testing capacity to expand, speed up and improve reliability. I want us to be measuring all those three things, not just one of them.

.@didoharding: This is a service that will encourage us all to be better at social distancing and good hand hygiene. Test and trace is not a silver bullet - if you have not been within 2m of someone outside your household for more than 15 minutes, you cannot be a close contact

Public Health England are responsible for holding the data for NHS Test & Trace. @didoharding says the scheme is being carried out in compliance with GDPR. She confirms the data won't be shared with any other Government body.
.@didoharding: I am not going to pretend that this is perfect... but there is a lot that we are doing that will enable us all to stay safer.

On concerns about fraud, @didoharding clarifies that NHS contact tracers will never ask for financial details and official phone numbers are listed on the https://t.co/vNHhjtIJ8V website. Anyone with concerns is advised to check the web URL they have been directed to carefully

.@didoharding: This is as much about local action as it is about national action. We all need to play our part - the Government is providing direct funding to local authorities for this https://t.co/ICuDB12KXJ

.@didoharding: I see test and trace as a multi-channel service. You need the bedrock of the end to end tracking and tracing service, which is why we've launched the NHS track and tracing service first. The app isn't core of this - but it will speed things up

.@didoharding: There are approximately 8,000 people contracting COVID-19 every day. At the moment we are testing 1,600 per day. Some 44% of adults are not aware that anyone who has symptoms can order a test
But, says @didoharding, the vast majority of people who are being asked to isolate are very happy to do so. We have contacted thousands of people in the first six days.
We are close to agreeing a weekly dashboard for test and trace data, but I don't have the data to share today, says @didoharding
The Committee is now beginning its questioning of Baroness @didoharding, head of NHS track and trace
Turnaround time is very important says @ChristoPhraser - and the daily reporting of testing should also publish how long turnaround times are

About 55,000 people on the Isle of Wight are using the NHS contact tracing app says @ChristoPhraser, which is pretty good considering the age of residents and level of smartphone usage. The next phase is focusing on how to better integrate the app with testing

On data gathered by the app, @ChristoPhraser says people must have trust in the system for an app to work. Sharing new types of data in the health system has led to substantial debate but research suggests most people support the use of the data for research in the NHS https://t.co/ChCw1guyvt
Singapore and Norway have achieved around 30% uptake for their apps but we need to build trust before these technologies can be proven on a national programme scale says @ChristoPhraser
For an app to be seen to be successful, it needs to be integrated and seen as part of a public health programme, says @ChristoPhraser, which will include manual contact tracing and social distancing.

You have four days from someone displaying #coronavirus symptoms to completing the test and trace process - and most people only come for a test after two days, meaning you really only have a two day window says @ChristoPhraser

We're now transitioning from a #StayAtHome  message to people coming forward and engaging with testing and tracing says @ChristoPhraser - it's fairly clear that countries which have managed to take that approach from the outset have fared better
People in Taiwan know that good health behaviour is good for you and your friends - it's a win win says Sir Chen Chien-jen https://t.co/hb8jPoZFtZ
Health education and risk communication is very important in Taiwan says Sir Chen Chien-jen. We have continuous education about maintaining good health behaviour from early years onwards

Taiwan amended its infection control laws in 2000 to enable contract tracing to be delivered during an outbreak, as well as to protect confidentiality. When privacy and confidentiality can be guaranteed, people are more likely to comply

The key element of success in Taiwan has been public trust in our public health policy and institutions, says Sir Chen Chien-jen, supported by effective and open communication enabling appropriate compliance
In Taiwan #coronavirus tests report within 1 day from over 140 sites, and it takes between 1 and 3 days from a positive result to perform a full contact tracing

Taiwan requires all inbound passengers from other countries to self-quarantine for 14 days. Civil and health workers make phone calls to everyone quarantined and use smart technology to help by allowing people to quickly provide updates on their health status
Sir Chen Chien-jen identifies 3 key elements to Taiwan's #coronavirus response: prudent action, rapid response and early deployment

@drjanetownson We discussed home care with the second panel of witnesses, including this important comment from @JamesBullion 

https://t.co/Vm0X49XeWt

Our session on the management of the #coronavirus outbreak has ended. We thank our witnesses - @AdelinaCoHe , @TerryLum , Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege , @ProfMartinGreen , @JamesBullion and @vicrayner https://t.co/znXbMXAhzT

@JamesBullion refers to the need for a long-term social care plan to sit alongside the NHS long-term plan, the regulation of the social care market, and the urgency not just of giving local authorities the money they need to fund social care, but deciding how to pay for it.
@vicrayner emphasises the need for a national minimum dataset for social care. We can‚Äôt plan without that data, she argues - it saves lives.

The big lessons we need to learn are about the integration between health and social care, the need for a workforce plan aligned to an NHS workforce plan which allows people to move across systems, and the need for a long term funding solution, says @ProfMartinGreen

Social care staff are going through a constant cycle of bereavement, losing people they are caring for to #Covid_19 , says @ProfMartinGreen . In hospitals there has been a focus on bereavement and trauma support and we need the same support for care home staff, adds @vicrayner
@JamesBullion agrees: ‚ÄúWe have been sleepwalking without a workforce strategy for adult social care for five years now, with huge turnover rates and no career grade structure.‚Äù
In the longer term we have got to completely redefine social care work, with proper alignment with the NHS, financing, training and qualifications, says @ProfMartinGreen

We need to enable a care environment which is not just about safety and infection control, but about protecting people's quality of life as well, says @vicrayner . Our hugely skilled social care staff will play a vital role in this.

Responding to the argument from @ProfMartinGreen about localism, @JamesBullion argues that local govt has stood up well, and that national approaches to testing and #PPE have not worked. Localism has actually worked well in terms of delivering PPE and testing to local providers.

Care providers need the money to help them ensure the safety of their residents and staff, @JamesBullion tells the Committee. They have seen enormous increases in their #PPE costs. The funding allocated to local authorities is only a quarter of what is needed.
We need a national strategy, argues @ProfMartinGreen - what we've seen is that localism is not fit for purpose in a crisis. We need clear central direction from central Government.

There wasn't a recognition in the 2016 planning process or at the start of this pandemic that the most vulnerable people are in care homes, says @ProfMartinGreen . Pandemic planning did not comprehensively overview social care or understand that it was a very diverse system.

We had a policy of emptying hospitals and filling care homes, @ProfMartinGreen tells the Committee, whereas other countries have had a policy of taking people out of care homes, if there was difficulty in isolating them.

Social care staff are doing a remarkable job in incredibly difficult circumstances, says @vicrayner , and the last thing we want is for those people to feel like they are responsible for the spread of #Covid_19

The Committee discusses the role of staff moving between #carehomes in spreading #Covid_19 . @AdelinaCoHe tells the Committee that in Canada, Israel and Singapore, staff have been prevented from working in multiple care homes.

For managing a second wave, it's absolutely critical that we have regular repeat testing, and that the results come through rapidly, argues @vicrayner . The 30,000 tests a day we have will enable us to test everyone in care homes, but only once - not repeatedly.

We have seen about 10% of people stopping their personal assistant care and #homecare to try to protect themselves from infection - but this can have serious health risks and consequences in itself, adds @JamesBullion

When we look at the figures, both the deaths and figures for transmission suggest we have difficulties in #homecare, says @JamesBullion . The response in this area has been totally inadequate so far and we need a separate plan for the domiciliary care sector.

We still don‚Äôt have an effective supply chain for #PPE, says @JamesBullion . If we had had a national planning on PPE we'd be far ahead of where we are now - some of the problems we are seeing in transmission are a result of this, and, sadly, some of the deaths too.

An international partnership approach is needed, says @vicrayner . We have lots of examples where homes have remodelled for social distancing but they have not been picked up nationally. Most of our stock is old and set up for people to come together and share space.
We should have been focusing on care homes from the start of the pandemic, says @ProfMartinGreen - the focus on the NHS often meant that care homes lost out on medical support and PPE.

We've had the announcements, @ProfMartinGreen tells the Committee, but there's been a time delay- we haven't had the delivery. We need testing and track-and-trace together to be able to make a difference.

Testing is crucial, argues @ProfMartinGreen . Testing is improving, but there are logistical issues and significant time delays - of up to 8-10 days. We need regular testing, 2-3 times a week, if we are to really get on top of this.
We are at the top of curve and heading downwards now, in terms of the #carehome home epidemic, says @ProfMartinGreen

We are now hearing form the second panel of witnesses - @AdelinaCoHe @ProfMartinGreen @JamesBullion and @vicrayner , for our session on the management of the #coronavius outbreak. 

üì∫: https://t.co/VR6UuFUpPK
Or follow us for more live tweetsüëá
There is a sharing of experience within the EU Commission on best practice in #carehomes, but it‚Äôs not clear if this is happening at the WHO level, says Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege

We know that if you get infected with #COVID„Éº19 it's not just you but the whole family and the extended family, says @TerryLum . In Hong Kong scientific experts have given information in a way that everyone can understand.
‚Ä¶ In nursing homes, there is a designated area for visitors, but there is a strict protocol for visitors entering nursing homes including temperature checks, hand sanitiser and face masks.
It is very hard to stop the virus spreading in care homes once it is there, so preventative measures to keep the virus out of #carehomes are critical, according to Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege ‚Ä¶

Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege tells the Committee that #carehomes in Germany would not take patients from hospitals unless they had the ability to isolate them for two weeks, following experience of asymptomatic patients bringing the disease into care homes.
Each #carehome must now start to have good technical support on their isolation capabilities and we need to improve the connection with local information about disease spread, warns @AdelinaCoHe

Germany was very strict with the lockdown, including in #carehomes, where only those directly providing care were allowed in, says Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege . In long term care homes there was a requirement to wear full protective equipment at the end of March.

In HK everyone has a high sense of vulnerability after SARS, so early on people started taking action such as wearing face masks, @TerryLum continues. All staff in nursing homes were required to wear masks from late Jan, and from early Feb, visits to care homes were stopped.

People have a very strong sense of responsibility in Hong Kong and acted quickly in response to the emerging pandemic, says @TerryLum . The infection control process was started in mid January, before we had a single case.

Thirdly is co-ordination, Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege  continues. After SARs, we realised that care homes lacked a co-ordinator to manage infection control. Now all care homes have a single point of contact who manages infection control and plays a crucial role.

Stopping the transmission from hospitals to #carehomes is the most important factor, Isabell Halletz @AGVpflege argues. Secondly we do a very good job of isolation, not just of the infected person but also of their contacts, who are tested repeatedly for a 14 day period.

Hospital discharge is a very big risk for #carehome residents, according to Isabell Halletz. In Germany, patients have to provide a negative test result, or they are quarantined for 14 days in a separate section of the care home or a separate 'stop over' quarantine facility.

Not a single person has died of #Covid-19 in a South Korean #carehome, @AdelinaCoHe tells the Committee. Anyone with suspected COVID was removed from care homes and placed in isolation either in hospital or a quarantine place. Singapore responded similarly swiftly.
We need very good awareness of local infection rates, and then testing for all #carehome residents and staff, including contact tracing, and isolation, @AdelinaCoHe says.
Being realistic about the ability of #carehomes to be isolation centres is key, and we need to be reasonable about what we are expecting them to do, @AdelinaCoHe continues.
Having large numbers of deaths in care homes is not inevitable, argues @AdelinaCoHe . Community control is essential - if you don't have COVID in the community, you don't have it in care homes.

Our session on Delivering Core NHS and Care Services during the Pandemic and Beyond has now ended. We thank our witnesses - @ChrisCEOHopson, @RichardDMurray, @nedwards_1 and @JenniferTHF. 

You can watch the session here: https://t.co/z99k4mm90B
Asked by Committee member @drlukeevans what has surprised him the most about the response to #Covid, @RichardDMurray1 asks how we were so slow when we saw what had happened in Europe.

We have effectively shrunk our bed numbers too low and very large numbers of hospitals have insufficient capacity in their emergency departments, says @ChrisCEOHopson , so we need a serious capital investment as we move forward.

Capital investment has been slow, argues @JenniferTHF : it has kept the service ticking over but not enough to modernise. We need to think about having reserve capacity in the system, and take a longer look at how technology has a long-term therapeutic effect on patients.

@JenniferTHF , @RichardDMurray1  and @nedwards_1 all agree that it is too soon to bring in legislative changes. The pandemic has shown that organisations are already able to collaborate when they need to. Providing answers on social care should be the priority.

Asked about the proposed #NHS Bill, @ChrisCEOHopson argues that we probably don't have the national architecture right--as we have seen with testing. We need to be careful about having management and accountability too far away from frontline care, he says.

@RichardDMurray1 tells the Committee there are a whole range of steps that can be taken to ensure that the leadership of organisations respects the diversity of their staff. #Covid should make us even more determined to overcome longstanding inequalities.
What #Covid has done has exacerbated known #inequalities in the population, argues @JenniferTHF, and now is the time for an equalities strategy.

The scientific consensus on why #BAME staff and citizens are more at risk from #Covid is not clear, but they certainly appear to be and this means we must increase the use of #PPE and other measures to keep this group safe, says @RichardDMurray1

One of the consistent issues that has been raised with our CEOs is that #PPE appears not to fit particular groups, such as BAME staff; CEOs are trying to source the right type of masks, and where that's not possible they have been considering redeployment, says @ChrisCEOHopson
‚Ä¶and if there is one thing that #Covid has taught us, it's that the social care workforce needs to be considered along with the health service.
We need to make sure that the People Plan, with its focus on morale, really builds on the experience of staff during #Covid so it is both welcome and deliverable, advises @RichardDMurray1 ‚Ä¶

@ChrisCEOHopson says at the moment Trusts cannot guarantee sufficient reliable and consistent access to tests for #NHS staff in a timely way. There are still significant problems with laboratory capacity and access to reagents and chemicals.
At the moment the assistance for the #voluntarysector has simply not been enough, @JenniferTHF tells the Committee, and this is affecting what they can do to help the health service.

@nedwards_1  expresses concern that #dentists haven‚Äôt been given any instructions about how to safely run a dental practice. There is no sign of them opening as we don't really know what prevention and infection control measures that we will need.

We are already starting to see significant increases in #mentalhealth demand, in particular among those hit by the economic and social consequences of lockdown, says @ChrisCEOHopson. Too little of the extra funding promised has yet reached the front line.

There is a particular challenge for #mentalhealth  services, says @RichardDMurray1 , because they started from a lower point than many physical health services. We need to build up MH services in the same way as was done with other services pre-#Covid
Staff are working under constraints they have simply never seen before and are therefore exhausted, which is concerning our trust leaders as we look to ramp up services, says @ChrisCEOHopson .     ..
We are experiencing what it is like to have a middle-income country health system with the standards and expectations of a high-income country, observes @nedwards_1 .

NHS staff have worked incredibly hard and done exceptional things, including cancelling leave, and are very tired, says @ChrisCEOHopson--they need a break. There should be an element of public debate about what we focus on as we move forwards in reinstatement of services.

Most A&E depts do not have the physical capacity to do social distancing, says @nedwards_1. He advises following the Norway and Denmark model, where individuals only use A&E after referrals--otherwise we will need a lot of additional space that needs to be staffed.
Trusts are telling us that this next phase is going to be more difficult than the phase we've just gone through, says @ChrisCEOHopson, not least because of the challenges posed by social distancing.

The key to avoiding a spike in cancer mortality is just how quickly cancer referrals pick up again, @RichardDMurray1  tells the Committee. Referrals have dropped sharply, but are now rising again, and have doubled, back up to 20,000 per week.

It is going to be very difficult to go back to what we had in A+E before the #COVID crisis, warns @nedwards_1. We haven't got the testing or #PPE in place to restart elective care as fast as we might like. We are very likely to see waiting lists of 8 million by late autumn.

Infection control is going to be number one in the minds of NHS staff and leaders at the moment, so there will be a lot more testing, cleaning and PPE which will inevitably slow things down, says @JenniferTHF

The three topics raised in today‚Äôs session will be:
1. Patient concerns
2. The view of NHS staff
3. Lessons learnt (good and bad) for the future

We have finished our session with Sir Patrick Vallance and Dr Jenny Harries in connection with our inquiry into the Management of the Coronavirus Outbreak. 

üì∫ Re-watch the session here: https://t.co/KwPL2Fko0j

ü§îKeep up-to-date with this inquiry here: https://t.co/T46iskNzbG https://t.co/XX6Ip8vPUP

Sir Patrick Vallance @uksciencechief tells us that "if we do test, trace and track well and keep social distancing measures at the right level, we should be able to avoid a second peak, but winter will be very difficult particularly with other infections like flu circulating"

Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy Chief Medical Officer, is unable to give us an answer as to how many tests are needed. She explains that this depends on a variety of changing factors such as local circumstances, but the 100,000 puts us in a very good place #Coronavirus

She clarifies that the scientific advice on large gatherings would have come from SAGE but the decision on individual cases would not be something for the scientific committee  or the Chief Medical Officer to take - it was an individual decision for the Government

Dr Jenny Harries: it's not possible to say whether Liverpool-Athletico Madrid match seeded further cases in the North West, it is possible that there were already other community cases at that point. The decision about whether a match would go ahead is not one for the CMO or SAGE

On whether international travel should have been suspended earlier, Dr Jenny Harries says that the risks as well as benefits need to be considered. Sir Patrick adds: that stopping travel from a single place will not work, you have to be draconian and stop travelling everywhere

Dr Jenny Harries adds: The plan as it stood was sensible, logical and based on good traditional public health practice. However we perhaps didn't think through the digital progression and opportunity. We have moved very swiftly on establishing research more coherently and rapidly
Sir Patrick says: his and his colleagues' judgements based on scientific information, not scientific certainties.

When asked "what would you have done differently?" Sir Patrick says that "probably in the early phases, if we had managed to ramp up testing capacity quicker it would have been beneficial...testing is not the answer, it's part of the system you have to get right"
Sir Patrick confirms in answering the Committee's questions that "there is a lot of work going on right now which is looking at how measures to lift lock-downs are working in other countries"
@uksciencechief  continues: The plan now is to get the number of new cases back down to a manageable number as part of a system that can pick up small local outbreaks early. #coronavirus

Sir Patrick adds: at the early stages, it absolutely was about trying to contain, isolate and track every case in the UK which were imported from the original outbreak in China. Then it became clear that we were having a massive influx of cases from multiple European sources
Sir Patrick Vallance @uksciencechief says that "right from the very first meeting on the pandemic, on 22 January 2020, we raised the issue of testing and tracking, and continually thereafter"

On of preventing #covid cases increasing exponentially, Dr Harries says: we are at a different point on the epidemic curve. Social distancing measures have pushed the rate down and removed a lot of transmission in the population. We should be able to identify & control new cases

When asked what is the number of new cases we need to reach in order for contact tracing to work, Dr Harries says: if the R number is and stays down, and we have tested methods of doing this - as are currently being trialled in the Isle of Wight - then we can move to this soon

Dr Jenny Harries says that why we are seeing more coronavirus-related deaths in BAME communities is unclear:  once higher levels of chronic disease amongst BAME individuals are taken into account, as well as socio-economic conditions, it becomes a very complex picture.

We are currently hearing from Sir Patrick Vallance @uksciencechief and Dr Jenny Harries in connection with our "Management of the Coronavirus Outbreak". Watch live here: https://t.co/KwPL2Fko0j https://t.co/Dfep7vw6pt

Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy CMO, tells us that the broad number of tests that haven taken place in Germany is the similar to the number of tests carried out in Italy - testing per se is not enough, it is the follow up afterwards. Watch our session live here: https://t.co/KwPL2Fko0j

She adds: In South Korea they had more focused outbreaks where contact tracing could be done more easily than in countries with widespread community transmission....The "Test Test Test" mantra from the World Health Organisation came at a time when many countries were not testing
Dr Jenny Harries: if the UK had unending capacity to test and pursue contact tracing then it might have been appropriate to continue with this in the UK.

Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy Chief Medical Officer, tell us that we will have to wait until the end of the pandemic to do robust comparisons between countries' death rates, and even then it will be very difficult because different countries collect data in very different ways

He says: very young children tend to have less contact outside their own households compared to older children so they may be less likely to promote onward transmission between households #coronavirus

On the topic of transmission amongst children, Sir Patrick adds: the evidence is that children are unlikely to be higher than adults in terms of transmission of coronavirus and may in fact be lower, but the evidence is not yet compelling

@uksciencechief says it is very clear that children are at much lower risk of clinical disease and severe disease - this is not zero risk, but very much reduced. There is also reasonable evidence to suggest that they are at lower risk of getting symptomatic disease.
He adds: There are pros and cons of releasing measures on a local level rather than a national one but it is an option, although there are issues around transport if you do that.

Sir Patrick says: the "R" varies slightly across the country but there isn't huge variation - it might be 0.6 in London and 0.7 elsewhere for example. Densely populated areas have higher prevalence than rural areas.

In presenting advice to Ministers, SAGE tries to focus on to two or three options, set out the reasons behind these options, but also  the relevant uncertainties - SAGE does not act in a "here is the answer, get on with it" way when advising the Government

Dr Jenny Harries, Deputy Chief Medical Officer, tells us that for many elderly people in care homes there appears to be a different presentation of the disease, which has made its management more difficult #COVID„Éº19 https://t.co/L2ds9Ir8gp

@uksciencechief says it is very hard to give an overall estimate of 'R' (rate of infection) in care homes as they are spread around the country but bringing this under control, as well as transmission in hospitals, is critical to the overall control of the epidemic #COVID„Éº19

Sir Patrick says the rules are very clear: people should still be social distancing, washing their hands regularly and avoiding touching their faces. These are much more significant factors than face masks in reducing transmission #covid-19

He adds: SAGE's evidence suggests that there is a marginal but positive effect on preventing the spread of coronavirus in the community. SAGE's evidence suggests that there is a marginal but positive effect of wearing masks on preventing the spread of coronavirus in the community

Sir Patrick Vallance @uksciencechief tells us that he thinks that the most highly infectious time is a day or two before symptoms starts and a day or two after symptoms start. This means asymptomatic transmission may be a cause of transmission.

When asked about the lack of economists working for SAGE, Sir Patrick says that the current practice is for economic factors to come in after SAGE has given its advice to Government. #coronavirusuk  Watch our session live here: https://t.co/KwPL2Fko0j

In response to questioning from our "guest" Greg Clark MP, Chair of @CommonsSTC , Sir Patrick says that SAGE are looking at total excess deaths with senior statisticians in order to take into account deaths from economic causes

Sir Patrick says that he is a strong advocate of transparency and openness, and as Chair of SAGE he has ensured papers from SAGE are published and will continue to do so as quickly as possible. He says: his focus is on giving Ministers advice and not making information  public https://t.co/kGJ4zQQQpv
@uksciencechief Sir Patrick says: [...] inevitably we are learning as we go along, and as we learn we will become more informed about which decisions we should take

He adds: the evidence  from around the world and the UK suggests that people get an antibody response post viral infection. But we don't know the degree of immune protection that this will provide, we don't know whether it provides absolute immunity or protection to other people

Sir Patrick tells us that we will get better ideas of the replication rate of the virus by community testing. He says that there are essentially 3 rates of infection at the moment, in the community, in hospitals and in care homes.

.@Jeremy_Hunt, Chair of the Committee, begins the session by thanking Dr Jenny Harries and Sir Patrick Vallance @uksciencechief and their teams for the work they have been doing to tackle the outbreak

Our session on delivering core NHS and care services during #coronavirus and beyond has now ended. Thanks to the witnesses @MartinRCGP @GillWaltonRCM Dame Cally Palmer and Claire Murdoch from @NHSEngland 

You can watch the session here: https://t.co/vMlC8lpAqA https://t.co/FWdST7MeAp

General practice is open - particularly for significant health problems like suspected cancer, mental health problems, and other crucial services like vaccination says @MartinRCGP 

#HeretoHelp

Prof Marshall @MartinRCGP says that we know that a lot of younger people don't access health care of any sort, including general practice. We hope that the use of new technologies for consultation will improve the numbers of young people coming forward

Prior to #Covid19 70% of GP consultations were face to face - now it is about 23%. After the pandemic, it may be around 50%. Although a growing number of GPs have the technology and training for remote consultations, more investment is needed to secure this says @MartinRCGP
Primary care networks have been given a lease of life by the #coronavirus crisis. We expect and hope they will be more embedded in the service as a consequence says @MartinRCGP

@MartinRCGP says there has been a massive crisis in GP numbers in recent years so it has been very gratifying to see large numbers of recently retired GPs returning in this crisis. We are working on measures to help them stay on

In the early days of the crisis, a lot of referral services including #dementia services were closed down, but things are slowly improving, says Professor Martin Marshall @MartinRCGP, Chair of Council at Royal College of General Practitioners
Claire Murdoch, National Mental Health Director @NHSEngland says we need the best evidence and modelling possible to tell us what is going to be needed to see our citizens through a challenging time

We don't yet know what additional demand will be as a result of¬†#COVID19. We know that¬†#PTSD¬†is prevalent among those who have been on ventilators, and bereaved people says Claire Murdoch, National Mental Health Director¬†@NHSEngland

National Mental Health Director¬†says there are 3 tiers of mental health support for NHS staff: 1) reinforcing good team behaviours, 2) all trusts are investing in more occupational mental health support, and 3) NHSE/I are investing in national 24/7 helplines with the third sector

Claire Murdoch, National Mental Health Director¬†@NHSEngland¬†tells us that referrals to¬†#mentalhealth¬†services for youngsters and children has been around 370,000 per year. After lock-down is lifted, she expects there to be a surge in referrals of an additional 340,000 (approx)
We know there is a good correlation between economic opportunity and #mentalhealth, says Claire Murdoch, National Mental Health Director @NHSEngland

There is absolutely no evidence of a spike in suicides or self harm, says Claire Murdoch, National Mental Health Director 
@NHSEngland, but we are pretty sure that levels of distress - anxiety, worry, depression - have gone up in young people, and adults too

We think there will be between 30-40% reduction in referrals to #CAMHS, but our message is - come through the emergency system or through primary care, we are still open for referrals - says Claire Murdoch, National Mental Health Director 
@NHSEngland

Dame Cally Palmer's message for the public - if you have signs or symptoms of cancer, come forward so we can give you the best outcome @NHSEngland 

#HeretoHelp

There have been no national instructions on screening says National Cancer Director. It's important to make sure that rescheduled screening take place, especially #bowelcancer. Cancers are slow growing so 4-6 weeks should not affect survival but we need to get that turned back on
Dame Cally Palmer says @NHSEngland are working out the extra resources we need to meet pent up demand for #cancerservices, including the independent sector
Recruitment to new cancer trials has stopped but existing trials are going on as normal says Dame Cally Palmer - recruitment should be back up and running in mid-May
It is important that we continue with our screening for cancer, says National Cancer Directors @NHSEngland, and we need to get that turned back on as a priority

We are working to ensure we have the workforce and, in particular, prioritisation of cancer staff to enable us to restart non-urgent cancer services up as soon as possible says National Cancer Director, Dame Cally Palmer

Dame Cally Palmer @NHSEngland says that restarting cancer diagnostics will be more complicated - we have to make sure we have protected capacity for endoscopy and other cancer diagnostics going forward

National Cancer Director at¬†@NHSEngland¬†states that work is ongoing with cancer alliances to step up services beginning with those who are in a life-threatening position, and then moving on to others. We are determined to make sure we have a plan for restoring services in place
Dame Cally Palmer @NHSEngland says central triaging means that we are able to flex demand and supply as never before across areas and organisational boundaries

Where surgery is considered not to be immediately urgent or too risky in a #Covid19 environment, we are ensuring these patients will be called in when we can, says National Cancer Director @NHSEngland
Dame Cally Palmer says the way people have adapted models for diagnostics and treatment to manage patient pathways has been amazing. 'I am optimistic that we will meet Long Term Plan targets'

Managing the restoration of cancer care will depend on ensuring we can segregate workforce and treatment space to ensure cancer patients can be treated in a #COVID19-free environment says Dame Cally Palmer, National Cancer Director¬†@NHSEngland

There has been a 62% reduction in urgent 2 week wait cancer referrals says Dame Cally Palmer, National Cancer Director¬†.@NHSEngland but it's unlikely that we will be missing huge numbers of cancers as urgent referrals and treatment are continuing
Maternity services are open, women must access their normal appointments, and contact their midwives as usual, says .@GillWaltonRCM and there is still the joy nationwide of babies being born

Both .@GillWaltonRCM and .@MartinRCGP
confirm the impact that the reduction in health visitors has had, saying that numbers have been 'decimated'
.@GillWaltonRCM says that increased virtual support might mean that women at risk of #domesticabuse are able to have contact from midwives

I am delighted that women have been able to continue taking their birthing partner to support them in labour, apart, of course, if the partner has¬†#coronavirus¬†symptoms, in which case women are encouraged to choose a different partner says¬†@GillWaltonRCM

@GillWaltonRCM says during #COVID19 women have become more anxious and we have seen increasing referrals to perinatal mental health teams. The first point of call for all pregnant women who are feeling anxious should always be to call their midwife.

In response to a question from Committee member Laura Trott @GillWaltonRCM says that care in labour in maternity units has been business as usual  - it is essential that anaesthetists are maintained as essential parts of maternity teams
@GillWaltonRCM says re-stepping midwifery services up to what they were before and better is everybody's aim
During #coronavirus whilst some face to face contacts have reduced, virtual contacts have increased. That is a good thing says @GillWaltonRCM
@GillWaltonRCM expresses concern related to both BAME pregnant women and BAME staff. Midwives are aware of this, and are treating BAME women as a more vulnerable group
@GillWaltonRCM emphasises that maternity services are still there, still open, and that women should come forward and keep their appointments so that they and their babies can receive the right care

Healthy over 70s should avoid crowded places, reduce unnecessary travel, don't go out unless they absolutely have to. You can go for a walk avoiding close contact with people. No Sunday lunch with their families either, says @uksciencechief 

#COVID19 #covid„Éº19uk

We are keen to only intervene at the appropriate moment to minimise the social disruption whilst maximising the public health impact, says @CMO_England

.@CMO_England If this follows the course of a typical epidemic, we'll get 50% of cases over a 3 week period and 90% over a 9 week period. There will therefore be a period, if this goes to the top end of the range, when the NHS has huge pressure on it for a short period of time
